case_id: 2024-08-12_USCOURTS-cand-3_23-cv-00201_Andersen et al v. Stability AI Ltd. et al.pdf
case_name: Andersen et al. v. Stability AI Ltd. et al.
ai_relevance: Dispute over using artists’ copyrighted works to train AI image generator Stable Diffusion, which allegedly outputs images imitating plaintiffs’ artistic styles.
ai_presence: The case centers on an AI software known as Stable Diffusion, an image-generating model allegedly trained on plaintiffs’ copyrighted artworks without permission. Plaintiffs allege that Stability AI and related defendants used their artworks as training data so the AI can produce images that imitate their artistic styles. The court analyzes whether using copyrighted artworks to train AI models like Stable Diffusion constitutes direct copyright infringement and addresses related claims, including those under the DMCA, arising from the AI training and output process.

parties.plaintiff_description: Group of individual visual artists, plaintiffs
parties.defendant_description: AI companies and online art platform defendants

claims.claim: Direct copyright infringement based on use of plaintiffs’ artworks to train Stable Diffusion and generate images imitating their styles.
claims.legal_basis: Copyright Act, 17 U.S.C. § 101 et seq. (direct infringement of exclusive rights in copyrighted works).
claims.outcome: Motions to dismiss denied in part; direct copyright infringement claims allowed to proceed against all defendants.

claims.claim: Digital Millennium Copyright Act violations related to removal or alteration of copyright management information in connection with AI training and outputs.
claims.legal_basis: DMCA, 17 U.S.C. § 1202 (prohibiting removal or alteration of copyright management information and distribution of works with such information removed).
claims.outcome: DMCA claims dismissed with prejudice for failure to meet statutory pleading requirements; not allowed to be repleaded.

claims.claim: Unjust enrichment based on defendants’ alleged benefit from using plaintiffs’ artworks to develop and commercialize Stable Diffusion and related AI services without compensation.
claims.legal_basis: State-law unjust enrichment (equitable restitution) potentially overlapping with federal copyright law.
claims.outcome: Unjust enrichment claims dismissed with leave to amend due to possible Copyright Act preemption; plaintiffs permitted to replead with additional facts.

defenses.defense: Insufficient allegations that training AI on copyrighted works and generating images constitutes direct copyright infringement.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal pleading standards under Fed. R. Civ. P. 12(b)(6) and 8(a); challenge to plausibility of infringement theory.

defenses.defense: DMCA claims fail because plaintiffs did not adequately allege removal, alteration, or distribution of works with missing copyright management information.
defenses.legal_basis: 17 U.S.C. § 1202 requirements and case law requiring specific factual allegations of CMI removal and scienter.

defenses.defense: Unjust enrichment claims are preempted by the Copyright Act because they do not contain extra elements beyond rights equivalent to copyright.
defenses.legal_basis: Copyright Act preemption, 17 U.S.C. § 301, barring state-law claims equivalent to exclusive rights under federal copyright.

case_id: 2023-10-30_USCOURTS-cand-3_23-cv-00201_Andersen et al v. Stability AI Ltd. et al.pdf
case_name: Andersen et al. v. Stability AI Ltd. et al.
ai_relevance: Dispute over training and use of AI image-generation model Stable Diffusion on artists’ copyrighted works without permission.
ai_presence: The case centers on defendants’ AI software product, Stable Diffusion, an image-generating artificial intelligence model. Plaintiffs allege that Stability AI, DeviantArt, and Midjourney used AI technology to train Stable Diffusion on billions of images, including plaintiffs’ copyrighted artworks, without authorization. The complaint asserts that Stable Diffusion was trained using plaintiffs’ works as part of its training dataset and that the model allegedly contains or relies on “compressed copies” of those training images. Plaintiffs claim that the AI model can generate new images in the style of specific artists, including the named plaintiffs, based on text prompts, and that this capability results from the AI having been trained on their copyrighted works. The court’s order discusses whether using copyrighted images to train an AI model constitutes direct copyright infringement, whether outputs of the AI model are derivative works, and whether the alleged “compressed copies” theory is plausible. The decision allows one direct copyright infringement claim related to the AI training (Andersen’s claim against Stability AI) to proceed, while dismissing other AI-related copyright, derivative work, DMCA, and related claims with leave to amend.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual visual artists bringing putative class action
parties.defendant_description: AI and online art companies offering image-generation tools

claims.claim: Direct copyright infringement by Stability AI for using Andersen’s artworks to train Stable Diffusion without permission.
claims.legal_basis: Copyright Act, 17 U.S.C. § 106 (exclusive rights in copyrighted works).
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied as to Andersen’s direct infringement claim against Stability AI; this claim proceeds.

claims.claim: Direct copyright infringement by Stability AI, DeviantArt, and Midjourney for using McKernan’s and Ortiz’s artworks to train Stable Diffusion and related tools.
claims.legal_basis: Copyright Act, 17 U.S.C. § 106.
claims.outcome: Dismissed for failure to plausibly allege copying of specific works or ownership; leave to amend granted.

claims.claim: Vicarious and/or contributory copyright infringement by DeviantArt and Midjourney based on their use and deployment of Stable Diffusion and related AI tools.
claims.legal_basis: Secondary copyright liability under the Copyright Act and related case law.
claims.outcome: Dismissed for insufficient factual allegations tying defendants’ conduct to specific infringements; leave to amend granted.

claims.claim: Creation and distribution of infringing derivative works by the AI systems’ outputs that allegedly mimic plaintiffs’ styles and incorporate their works.
claims.legal_basis: Copyright Act, 17 U.S.C. § 106(2) (exclusive right to prepare derivative works).
claims.outcome: Dismissed; court found allegations that all outputs are derivative of training images implausible as pled; leave to amend granted.

claims.claim: Violation of the Digital Millennium Copyright Act for removal or alteration of copyright management information in connection with training Stable Diffusion and generating outputs.
claims.legal_basis: DMCA, 17 U.S.C. § 1202 (copyright management information).
claims.outcome: Dismissed for lack of specific allegations of CMI removal and knowledge; leave to amend granted.

claims.claim: Right of publicity and related state-law claims based on alleged misuse of plaintiffs’ names and artistic styles in connection with AI outputs and marketing.
claims.legal_basis: State right of publicity and unfair competition statutes (e.g., California law).
claims.outcome: Dismissed for insufficiently specific and conclusory allegations; leave to amend granted.

claims.claim: Unfair competition and deceptive business practices related to the marketing and operation of AI image-generation services trained on copyrighted works without consent.
claims.legal_basis: State unfair competition laws (e.g., California Unfair Competition Law, Bus. & Prof. Code § 17200).
claims.outcome: Dismissed for failure to state a claim with adequate factual detail; leave to amend granted.

claims.claim: Unjust enrichment based on defendants’ alleged benefit from using plaintiffs’ copyrighted works to train and operate AI systems without compensation.
claims.legal_basis: State common-law unjust enrichment / restitution principles.
claims.outcome: Dismissed as duplicative or insufficiently pled; leave to amend granted.

defenses.defense: Plaintiffs failed to allege specific copyrighted works and concrete acts of copying tied to each defendant.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal pleading standards under Fed. R. Civ. P. 8 and 12(b)(6) requiring plausible, non-conclusory allegations.

defenses.defense: Stable Diffusion does not store or contain “compressed copies” of training images, and plaintiffs’ theory that every output is an infringing derivative work is implausible.
defenses.legal_basis: Plausibility requirement under Twombly/Iqbal and copyright doctrine distinguishing training data from stored copies and derivative works.

defenses.defense: Plaintiffs did not adequately allege removal or alteration of copyright management information or the requisite scienter for DMCA claims.
defenses.legal_basis: DMCA, 17 U.S.C. § 1202, and case law requiring specific CMI and knowledge allegations.

defenses.defense: State-law claims such as right of publicity, unfair competition, and unjust enrichment are inadequately pled, overly conclusory, or preempted or limited by federal copyright law.
defenses.legal_basis: Preemption under 17 U.S.C. § 301 and state-law pleading standards.

defenses.defense: Class allegations and broad theories of liability are unsupported by specific facts connecting each defendant’s conduct to each plaintiff’s alleged harm.
defenses.legal_basis: Rule 23 class action standards and Rule 12(b)(6) plausibility requirements.

case_id: 2025-03-19_USCOURTS-cand-3_23-cv-00201_Andersen et al v. Stability AI Ltd. et al.pdf
case_name: Andersen et al v. Stability AI Ltd. et al
ai_relevance: Dispute over training and use of generative AI model Stable Diffusion on artists’ copyrighted works without permission; AI system central to underlying copyright claims and drives discovery scope and ESI issues.
ai_presence: The case concerns “a generative AI model, Stable Diffusion,” allegedly trained on plaintiffs’ artworks without permission. The artists allege defendants “used their artworks without permission to train a generative AI model, Stable Diffusion,” constituting “widespread copyright infringement.” The court notes that discovery and ESI protocols must address “large volumes of data” in “a complex case involving AI technologies.”

parties.plaintiff_description: Group of visual artist plaintiffs
parties.defendant_description: Multiple AI and tech company defendants

claims.claim: Unauthorized use of plaintiffs’ visual artworks to train the Stable Diffusion generative AI model.
claims.legal_basis: Copyright infringement under federal copyright law (unauthorized reproduction and use of copyrighted works).
claims.outcome: Not resolved in this order; court only decides discovery and ESI protocol issues, underlying infringement claim proceeds.

claims.claim: Widespread copying and exploitation of plaintiffs’ artworks through operation and distribution of Stable Diffusion outputs.
claims.legal_basis: Copyright infringement and related copyright theories (e.g., derivative works, distribution).
claims.outcome: Not resolved in this order; merits reserved for later proceedings.

claims.claim: Request for expansive discovery, including broad ESI production and a high number of depositions, due to complexity of AI training and data usage.
claims.legal_basis: Federal Rules of Civil Procedure governing discovery (Rules 26, 30, 34, 37) and proportionality standards.
claims.outcome: Partially granted and partially limited; court sets modified ESI protocol and allows thirty depositions instead of the requested sixty, directing parties to file revised protocols consistent with the court’s modifications.

defenses.defense: Objection to plaintiffs’ proposed discovery scope, including burdensome ESI production and excessive number of depositions.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rules of Civil Procedure, especially Rule 26(b)(1) proportionality and Rule 30 deposition limits; arguments about burden and expense on defendants.

defenses.defense: Requests for narrower definitions and protections in the protective order and ESI protocol to limit disclosure of sensitive information.
defenses.legal_basis: Protective order standards under Rule 26(c) and ESI protocol practice, emphasizing confidentiality and burden reduction.

case_id: 2024-02-12_USCOURTS-cand-3_23-cv-03223_Tremblay et al v. OpenAI_ Inc. et al.pdf
case_name: Tremblay et al. v. OpenAI, Inc. et al.
ai_relevance: Dispute over training and operation of OpenAI’s ChatGPT AI language models on copyrighted books without authorization.
ai_presence: The case centers on OpenAI’s development and deployment of ChatGPT, described as an AI language model trained on large amounts of text, including allegedly copyrighted books. Plaintiffs allege that OpenAI used their copyrighted works, without consent or compensation, as training data for its AI models. The complaint asserts that ChatGPT’s training process involved copying and ingesting entire books to create and refine the AI system’s capabilities. The court’s order on the motion to dismiss discusses whether this use of copyrighted materials in training an AI model constitutes direct copyright infringement and whether the alleged conduct can support an unfair competition claim under California’s Unfair Competition Law. The opinion repeatedly refers to ChatGPT and OpenAI’s AI language models as the technological products whose training and outputs are at issue in the lawsuit.

parties.plaintiff_description: Authors bringing putative class action
parties.defendant_description: AI company and related entities

claims.claim: Direct copyright infringement based on use of plaintiffs’ books to train OpenAI’s AI language models (including ChatGPT) without authorization.
claims.legal_basis: Federal Copyright Act, 17 U.S.C. §§ 101 et seq.
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied; claim allowed to proceed at pleading stage.

claims.claim: Vicarious copyright infringement for allegedly profiting from and having the right and ability to control infringing uses of plaintiffs’ works by OpenAI’s AI models and outputs.
claims.legal_basis: Federal Copyright Act, 17 U.S.C. §§ 101 et seq. (vicarious liability doctrine).
claims.outcome: Dismissed for insufficient factual allegations; leave to amend granted to replead with more detail.

claims.claim: Violation of the Digital Millennium Copyright Act (DMCA) for removal or alteration of copyright management information in connection with use of plaintiffs’ works in training the AI models and generating outputs.
claims.legal_basis: Digital Millennium Copyright Act, 17 U.S.C. § 1202.
claims.outcome: Dismissed for failure to plead required elements and specific facts; leave to amend granted.

claims.claim: Negligence based on OpenAI’s alleged failure to exercise reasonable care in acquiring, using, and handling plaintiffs’ copyrighted works to train its AI models.
claims.legal_basis: State common-law negligence (duty, breach, causation, damages).
claims.outcome: Dismissed for lack of a cognizable duty and insufficient allegations; leave to amend granted.

claims.claim: Unjust enrichment based on OpenAI’s alleged retention of benefits from using plaintiffs’ copyrighted works to develop and commercialize its AI models without compensating the authors.
claims.legal_basis: State common-law unjust enrichment / restitution principles.
claims.outcome: Dismissed as not independently viable on the current pleadings; leave to amend granted.

claims.claim: Unfair competition based on “unfair” business practices in using copyrighted books without authorization to train and commercialize OpenAI’s AI models, thereby gaining an unfair advantage over competitors and authors.
claims.legal_basis: California Unfair Competition Law (UCL), Cal. Bus. & Prof. Code § 17200, “unfair” prong.
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied as to the unfair-prong theory; claim allowed to proceed on that basis.

claims.claim: Unfair competition based on “unlawful” and/or “fraudulent” prongs, predicated on the alleged copyright, DMCA, and other statutory violations.
claims.legal_basis: California Unfair Competition Law (UCL), Cal. Bus. & Prof. Code § 17200, “unlawful” and “fraudulent” prongs.
claims.outcome: Dismissed to the extent predicated on dismissed underlying claims; leave to amend granted consistent with amended underlying causes of action.

defenses.defense: Challenge to sufficiency of copyright infringement allegations, including lack of specific copying of protected expression and failure to plausibly link particular outputs to plaintiffs’ works.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6) failure to state a claim; copyright pleading standards.

defenses.defense: Argument that vicarious copyright infringement elements were not met because plaintiffs did not adequately allege OpenAI’s right and ability to supervise specific infringing acts or a direct financial interest in such acts.
defenses.legal_basis: Vicarious copyright infringement doctrine under the Copyright Act; Rule 12(b)(6).

defenses.defense: Argument that DMCA claims were deficient because plaintiffs did not plausibly allege removal or alteration of copyright management information with the requisite scienter or in connection with specific instances of infringement.
defenses.legal_basis: 17 U.S.C. § 1202 requirements; Rule 12(b)(6).

defenses.defense: Argument that negligence claim fails because OpenAI owed no cognizable tort duty to plaintiffs regarding use of copyrighted works in AI training and that the claim is preempted or duplicative of copyright law.
defenses.legal_basis: State negligence law (duty requirement) and federal copyright preemption principles; Rule 12(b)(6).

defenses.defense: Argument that unjust enrichment is not an independent cause of action or is preempted/duplicative of copyright claims, and that plaintiffs failed to allege a specific unjust retention of a benefit beyond the alleged infringement.
defenses.legal_basis: State unjust enrichment doctrine and federal copyright preemption; Rule 12(b)(6).

defenses.defense: Argument that UCL claims fail because plaintiffs did not allege a predicate unlawful act beyond the asserted copyright claims and did not adequately plead unfair or fraudulent conduct or economic injury.
defenses.legal_basis: California UCL pleading standards; Rule 12(b)(6).

case_id: 2019-11-21_USCOURTS-cand-3_19-cv-03132_UAB _Planner5D_ v. Meta Platforms_ Inc. et al.pdf
case_name: UAB Planner5D v. Meta Platforms, Inc. et al.
ai_relevance: Plaintiff alleges defendants scraped its 3D design dataset to develop and train AI-driven scene recognition and related computer vision technologies.
ai_presence: The summary states that defendants used automated "scraping" to illegally download Planner 5D’s proprietary 3D design data, which is crucial for AI-driven scene recognition technology. The data was allegedly used in connection with artificial intelligence research and development, including training machine learning models for scene recognition and related AI applications.

parties.plaintiff_description: Business providing online 3D interior design tools
parties.defendant_description: Technology company, university, and associated research collaborators

claims.claim: Copyright infringement based on alleged unauthorized copying and use of Planner 5D’s 3D design objects and scenes dataset via automated scraping.
claims.legal_basis: U.S. Copyright Act, including requirement of valid registration and protectable original expression.
claims.outcome: Dismissed without prejudice; court held plaintiff failed to sufficiently allege valid copyright registrations, originality of the asserted works, and specific infringing acts, but granted leave to amend.

claims.claim: Contributory and/or vicarious copyright infringement arising from defendants’ alleged use, distribution, or facilitation of use of the scraped dataset in AI-related research and products.
claims.legal_basis: Secondary liability doctrines under the U.S. Copyright Act (contributory and vicarious infringement).
claims.outcome: Dismissed without prejudice along with primary copyright claims; insufficient underlying infringement allegations and lack of specific facts, with leave to amend.

claims.claim: Trade secret misappropriation based on alleged taking and use of Planner 5D’s proprietary 3D design data and dataset structure.
claims.legal_basis: Federal Defend Trade Secrets Act (DTSA) and analogous state trade secret law (e.g., California Uniform Trade Secrets Act).
claims.outcome: Dismissed without prejudice; court found plaintiff did not adequately allege reasonable measures to maintain secrecy or sufficiently plead improper acquisition, use, or disclosure, but allowed amendment.

defenses.defense: Planner 5D failed to state a claim for copyright infringement because it did not adequately allege valid copyright registrations, originality, or specific infringing acts tied to registered works.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6); requirements under the U.S. Copyright Act for registration, originality, and plausible infringement allegations.

defenses.defense: Planner 5D failed to state a claim for trade secret misappropriation because it did not plausibly allege that the information was a trade secret, that reasonable measures were taken to maintain its secrecy, or that defendants acquired it through improper means.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6); Defend Trade Secrets Act and state trade secret statutes requiring secrecy, reasonable protective measures, and improper acquisition/use.

defenses.defense: Any access to Planner 5D’s website and data was authorized or not alleged to be unauthorized in a manner that would support misappropriation or other unlawful conduct claims.
defenses.legal_basis: General principles of trade secret and computer access law; Rule 12(b)(6) pleading standards for improper acquisition or unauthorized access.

case_id: 2025-06-25_USCOURTS-cand-3_23-cv-03417_Kadrey et al v. Meta Platforms_ Inc..pdf
case_name: Kadrey et al. v. Meta Platforms, Inc.
ai_relevance: Dispute over using copyrighted books as training data for Meta’s Llama generative AI large language models; court analyzes whether training these AI models on plaintiffs’ works is protected fair use.
ai_presence: The case centers on Meta’s development and use of generative AI models, specifically its Llama large language models. Plaintiffs allege Meta used their copyrighted books as training data to develop these AI systems. The court describes Meta’s use of the books to train its generative AI models and evaluates whether this training use—feeding the works into machine-learning algorithms to create and improve the Llama large language models—is a fair use under copyright law. The opinion characterizes Meta’s use as highly transformative because the books are not reproduced or output as such, but instead are ingested by the AI training process to adjust model parameters so the system can generate new text. The court ultimately holds that Meta’s use of plaintiffs’ works in training its Llama AI models is protected by the fair use doctrine, in part because plaintiffs did not provide sufficient evidence that this AI training caused cognizable market harm to their books.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual authors of copyrighted literary works
parties.defendant_description: Technology corporation operating social and AI platforms

claims.claim: Copyright infringement based on Meta’s use of plaintiffs’ books as training data for its Llama generative AI models.
claims.legal_basis: Federal copyright law, 17 U.S.C. § 106 (exclusive rights in copyrighted works).
claims.outcome: Court granted Meta’s motion for partial summary judgment, holding the training use of plaintiffs’ books for Llama models is protected as fair use; infringement claim fails as to that use.

claims.claim: Copyright infringement based on alleged market harm from Meta’s AI training use of plaintiffs’ works (loss of licensing or other markets).
claims.legal_basis: Federal copyright law fair use analysis under 17 U.S.C. § 107, focusing on the fourth factor (effect of the use upon the potential market).
claims.outcome: Court found plaintiffs failed to present sufficient evidence of actual or likely market harm from the AI training use; this weighed in favor of fair use and supported granting summary judgment for Meta on this aspect of the infringement claim.

defenses.defense: Fair use: Meta’s use of plaintiffs’ books to train its Llama generative AI models is highly transformative and does not cause cognizable market harm.
defenses.legal_basis: 17 U.S.C. § 107 (fair use doctrine) and associated case law interpreting transformative use and market effect.

case_id: 2025-07-30_USCOURTS-cand-5_23-cv-04534_Sage Global Services Limited et al v. 4th Paradigm _Beijing_ Technology Co._ Ltd..pdf
case_name: Sage Global Services Limited et al. v. 4th Paradigm (Beijing) Technology Co., Ltd.
ai_relevance: Dispute involves software and AI products branded with the SAGE mark allegedly infringing plaintiffs’ SAGE trademarks.
ai_presence: The summary states that the alleged trademark infringement was "in connection with software and AI products using the SAGE mark," indicating that the defendant’s offerings included AI products marketed under the disputed SAGE branding.

parties.plaintiff_name: Sage Global Services Limited; Sage Software, Inc.
parties.plaintiff_description: Corporate software businesses asserting SAGE trademarks
parties.defendant_description: Chinese technology company offering software and AI products

claims.claim: Trademark infringement based on defendant’s use of the SAGE mark on software and AI products.
claims.legal_basis: U.S. trademark law (likely Lanham Act) protecting the SAGE mark against unauthorized use causing confusion.
claims.outcome: Dismissed without reaching merits because the court found no personal jurisdiction over the defendant.

claims.claim: Related trademark and unfair competition claims arising from alleged misuse of the SAGE brand in commerce.
claims.legal_basis: Federal and/or state trademark and unfair competition laws requiring sufficient contacts for U.S. jurisdiction.
claims.outcome: Dismissed for lack of personal jurisdiction; court did not adjudicate liability.

defenses.defense: Lack of personal jurisdiction in California and the United States.
defenses.legal_basis: Due process and personal jurisdiction doctrines requiring sufficient minimum contacts for general or specific jurisdiction.

case_id: 2024-12-06_USCOURTS-cand-3_23-cv-03417_Kadrey et al v. Meta Platforms_ Inc..pdf
case_name: Kadrey et al. v. Meta Platforms, Inc.
ai_relevance: Plaintiffs allege Meta used copyrighted books to train Llama AI models without permission, challenging AI training datasets and related discovery responses.
ai_presence: The case centers on Meta’s large language models, including Llama, which plaintiffs allege were trained on datasets containing copyrighted books without authorization. Plaintiffs seek discovery about Meta’s dataset usage, including which books and sources were used to train the Llama AI models, and whether Meta obtained permission. The court’s discovery order addresses Meta’s obligations to disclose information about the training data, datasets, and versions of the Llama AI models (including Llama 5), and compels Meta to provide more complete responses and documents related to the AI training process.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual authors alleging copyright infringement
parties.defendant_description: Technology corporation operating AI and social platforms

claims.claim: Meta used plaintiffs’ copyrighted books without permission to train its Llama large language models.
claims.legal_basis: Copyright infringement under U.S. copyright law (unauthorized reproduction and use).
claims.outcome: Not resolved on the merits in this opinion; discovery order only. Court compelled Meta to provide more complete discovery responses related to training data and Llama models.

claims.claim: Meta copied and ingested copyrighted works into its training datasets and derivative AI models without authorization, creating infringing derivative works.
claims.legal_basis: Copyright infringement and creation of unauthorized derivative works under U.S. copyright law.
claims.outcome: Substantive liability not decided; court addressed only discovery. Certain discovery requests about datasets and model versions were granted in part and denied in part.

claims.claim: Meta failed to provide adequate responses to requests for admission regarding its use of copyrighted books and datasets in training Llama models.
claims.legal_basis: Federal discovery rules (Fed. R. Civ. P. 26, 36) governing completeness and sufficiency of responses to requests for admission.
claims.outcome: Court granted in part and denied in part plaintiffs’ motion to compel; Meta ordered to amend and clarify several RFA responses, including acknowledging coverage of Llama 5 where appropriate.

claims.claim: Meta’s responses to requests for production were incomplete or improperly limited, including by providing summaries instead of full documents about datasets and training materials for Llama models.
claims.legal_basis: Federal discovery rules (Fed. R. Civ. P. 26, 34) requiring production of responsive, non-privileged documents and forbidding undue limitation or substitution with summaries absent agreement.
claims.outcome: Court granted in part and denied in part plaintiffs’ motion to compel; Meta ordered to produce full documents rather than summaries for certain requests and to expand production to include additional Llama-related materials.

defenses.defense: Meta’s existing discovery responses and objections to requests for admission are sufficient and compliant with the Federal Rules.
defenses.legal_basis: Fed. R. Civ. P. 26 and 36; proportionality and specificity requirements for discovery and RFAs.

defenses.defense: Certain requested information and documents about Llama models, datasets, and training processes are irrelevant, overbroad, or disproportionate to the needs of the case.
defenses.legal_basis: Fed. R. Civ. P. 26(b)(1) proportionality and relevance limits on discovery.

defenses.defense: Meta may provide summaries or limited disclosures instead of full underlying documents for some discovery requests concerning datasets and AI training materials.
defenses.legal_basis: Fed. R. Civ. P. 26 and 34, interpreted to allow reasonable limitations and formats of production, subject to court oversight.

case_id: 2025-08-19_USCOURTS-ded-1_24-cv-01092_Hangzhou Jicai Procurement Co._ Ltd et al v. Anaconda_ Inc..pdf
case_name: Hangzhou Jicai Procurement Co., Ltd. et al. v. Anaconda, Inc.
ai_relevance: Dispute centers on contracts and alleged breaches involving Anaconda’s AI technology software used by Alibaba-related entities.
ai_presence: The summary states the case concerns “the validity and breach of contracts related to Anaconda's AI technology software.” The plaintiffs sought a declaratory judgment about “the Anaconda Agreements” governing use of this AI technology software, and the underlying Texas litigation involved alleged breach of those agreements in connection with use of Anaconda’s AI technology by Alibaba Group entities.

parties.plaintiff_description: Chinese corporate entities linked to Alibaba Group
parties.defendant_description: Software company providing AI technology tools

claims.claim: Request for declaratory judgment that the Anaconda Agreements are valid, properly interpreted, and/or not breached by Jicai and AliCloud in connection with their use of Anaconda’s AI technology software.
claims.legal_basis: Federal Declaratory Judgment Act and related contract law principles concerning the Anaconda Agreements.
claims.outcome: Dismissed without reaching the merits because the court found plaintiffs lacked Article III standing and therefore lacked subject matter jurisdiction.

claims.claim: Request for declaratory judgment that Anaconda’s pending Texas breach of contract litigation against other Alibaba Group entities does not create liability, obligations, or legal exposure for Jicai and AliCloud under the Anaconda Agreements.
claims.legal_basis: Federal Declaratory Judgment Act; Article III case-or-controversy requirement; contract law regarding parties and non-parties to agreements.
claims.outcome: Dismissed for lack of Article III standing; court held plaintiffs had no adverse legal interests or immediate, real threat of future harm from the Texas litigation.

defenses.defense: Plaintiffs lack Article III standing because they are not parties to the underlying Texas breach of contract suit and have not shown an immediate, substantial threat of injury from that litigation.
defenses.legal_basis: U.S. Constitution Article III case-or-controversy requirement; standing doctrine requiring injury in fact, causation, and redressability.

defenses.defense: No justiciable controversy exists between Anaconda and Jicai/AliCloud regarding the Anaconda Agreements because plaintiffs are not parties to the relevant agreements at issue in the Texas case and have not demonstrated adverse legal interests.
defenses.legal_basis: Declaratory Judgment Act requirements for an actual controversy; federal subject matter jurisdiction principles.

case_id: 2025-01-08_USCOURTS-cand-4_24-cv-01454_Nazemian et al v. NVIDIA Corporation.pdf
case_name: Nazemian et al. v. NVIDIA Corporation (consolidated with Dubus v. NVIDIA Inc.)
ai_relevance: Dispute involves protection of proprietary AI and machine-learning source code and technical materials during discovery and court filings.
ai_presence: The opinion concerns a protective order governing “sensitive, proprietary information, including AI technology and machine learning models.” It specifically addresses “proprietary technology related to artificial intelligence (AI),” including “source code for machine learning models and AI systems.” The order sets rules for the production, designation, and handling of “Confidential” and “Highly Confidential” material, with particular focus on “source code for machine learning models and AI systems” and other AI-related proprietary information in discovery and in court filings.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual plaintiffs in consolidated civil actions
parties.defendant_description: Technology corporation and AI hardware/software company

claims.claim: Request for court order governing treatment of confidential and highly confidential discovery material, including AI-related proprietary technology and source code.
claims.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 26(c) (protective orders) and parties’ stipulation in civil discovery.
claims.outcome: Granted; court entered stipulated protective order setting detailed procedures for designating, using, and filing confidential and highly confidential material, including AI-related source code.

defenses.defense: Need to prevent public and competitive disclosure of NVIDIA’s proprietary and trade-secret information, including AI and machine-learning technology, while allowing necessary discovery.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 26(c) good cause standard for protective orders; protection of trade secrets and confidential commercial information.

case_id: 2025-07-15_USCOURTS-ded-1_25-cv-00201_Aon Re_ Inc. v. Zesty.ai_ Inc..pdf
case_name: Aon Re, Inc. v. Zesty.AI, Inc.
ai_relevance: Patents cover machine-learning systems that analyze aerial property images to assess risk; dispute centers on whether this ML-based approach is patent-eligible under § 101.
ai_presence: The case concerns “patent infringement regarding patents that use machine learning to analyze aerial photographs of properties to assess risk.” The key legal issue is “whether the patents held by Aon Re, Inc., which employ machine learning to evaluate property risk from aerial images, are directed to an abstract idea and thereby qualify as patent-ineligible under 35 U.S.C. § 101.” The court held that the patents “recite a specific technological method involving two independently trained machine learning classifiers that analyze different aspects of a property, which provides a concrete and specific technological solution rather than a generalized use of technology.” The summary further explains that the invention uses “two super smart robot brains (algorithms) that each check different parts of the house to give a clearer result.”

parties.plaintiff_description: Corporate plaintiff, insurance and risk services.
parties.defendant_description: Technology company using AI for property risk.

claims.claim: Patent infringement based on use of machine-learning methods to analyze aerial property images for risk assessment covered by Aon’s patents.
claims.legal_basis: Federal patent law, including 35 U.S.C. §§ 271 et seq. (infringement of patents directed to ML-based property risk assessment).
claims.outcome: At motion-to-dismiss stage, court rejected defendant’s § 101 invalidity challenge and allowed Aon’s infringement claims to proceed.

claims.claim: Validity of Aon’s patents on machine-learning risk assessment methods challenged as being directed to an abstract idea and thus patent-ineligible.
claims.legal_basis: 35 U.S.C. § 101 (patent-eligibility; abstract idea doctrine).
claims.outcome: Court held the asserted patents are not directed to an abstract idea because they claim a specific arrangement of two independently trained machine-learning classifiers analyzing different property aspects; motion to dismiss on § 101 grounds denied.

defenses.defense: The asserted patents are invalid because they are directed to the abstract idea of risk assessment implemented with generic machine learning.
defenses.legal_basis: 35 U.S.C. § 101 (subject-matter eligibility; abstract idea and Alice/Mayo framework).

case_id: 2022-09-21_USCOURTS-cand-3_22-cv-02366_Shared Partnership v. Meta Platforms_ Inc..pdf
case_name: Shared Partnership v. Meta Platforms, Inc.
ai_relevance: NOT RELATED

parties.plaintiff_description: Canadian online content creator business
parties.defendant_description: U.S. social media and technology corporation

claims.claim: Breach of contract for restricting or removing Shared’s access to Facebook advertising and monetization services contrary to the parties’ agreements.
claims.legal_basis: State contract law; alleged violation of Facebook/Meta terms and related commercial agreements.
claims.outcome: Dismissed to the extent based on Meta’s decisions to remove or restrict content or services, because those actions were held immune under Section 230(c)(1) of the Communications Decency Act.

claims.claim: Breach of contract for failing to provide required notices, explanations for ad rejections, and other procedural obligations promised in Meta’s terms (including timing of payments).
claims.legal_basis: State contract law; enforcement of express contractual procedural obligations in Meta’s terms and policies.
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied; claim allowed to proceed because Section 230(c)(1) does not bar suits based on Meta’s independent contractual obligations such as notice and payment procedures.

claims.claim: Misrepresentation related to how Meta would treat Shared’s content, advertising, and monetization, including alleged misleading statements about access, enforcement, and review processes.
claims.legal_basis: State tort law for misrepresentation and/or fraudulent or negligent misrepresentation based on Meta’s statements and policies.
claims.outcome: Partially dismissed where premised on content-removal decisions covered by Section 230(c)(1); allowed to proceed to the extent based on Meta’s independent promises and representations not inherently tied to publisher decisions over third-party content.

defenses.defense: Section 230(c)(1) of the Communications Decency Act bars claims arising from Meta’s decisions to remove, restrict, or moderate content and access to its platform.
defenses.legal_basis: 47 U.S.C. § 230(c)(1) immunity for interactive computer service providers acting as publishers of third-party content.

defenses.defense: Meta complied with, and acted within, the scope of its contractual terms and policies governing advertising, monetization, and account enforcement.
defenses.legal_basis: Contract interpretation and limitation of obligations under Meta’s terms of service and related policies.

case_id: 2022-12-06_USCOURTS-cand-3_20-cv-08570_Klein et al v. Meta Platforms_ Inc..pdf
case_name: Klein et al. v. Meta Platforms, Inc.
ai_relevance: Plaintiffs allege Meta used AI and machine-learning driven advertising tools and algorithms as part of a broader scheme to maintain monopoly power and inflate prices in the social advertising market, contributing to the alleged anticompetitive conduct.
ai_presence: The summary indicates that plaintiffs claim Meta “used a variety of anticompetitive tactics, including integrating artificial intelligence and machine learning models, to maintain its dominance.” The court’s order notes that the amended complaint plausibly alleges anticompetitive conduct that includes Meta’s integration and use of AI and ML technologies in its social advertising products and systems as part of the alleged monopolization of the social advertising market.

parties.plaintiff_description: Facebook advertisers bringing antitrust class action
parties.defendant_description: Social media and digital advertising corporation

claims.claim: Monopolization of the social advertising market by Meta, resulting in inflated advertising prices for Facebook advertisers.
claims.legal_basis: Section 2 of the Sherman Act (monopolization).
claims.outcome: Court denied Meta’s motion to dismiss; monopolization claim allowed to proceed based on plausibly alleged anticompetitive conduct, including use of AI and ML tools.

claims.claim: Attempted monopolization of the social advertising market through exclusionary and anticompetitive tactics, including AI- and ML-driven systems.
claims.legal_basis: Section 2 of the Sherman Act (attempted monopolization).
claims.outcome: Court denied Meta’s motion to dismiss; attempted monopolization claim allowed to proceed as sufficiently and plausibly pleaded.

claims.claim: Conspiracy or agreement that unreasonably restrained trade in the social advertising market, helping Meta maintain its dominance and overcharge advertisers.
claims.legal_basis: Section 1 of the Sherman Act (unreasonable restraint of trade).
claims.outcome: Court denied Meta’s motion to dismiss; Section 1 claim found plausibly alleged and allowed to move forward.

claims.claim: Maintenance of monopoly power through integration of AI and machine learning models into Meta’s advertising products and systems to entrench dominance and stifle competition.
claims.legal_basis: Section 2 of the Sherman Act (maintenance of monopoly power through exclusionary conduct).
claims.outcome: Court held that allegations regarding AI/ML integration form part of a plausible theory of anticompetitive conduct; motion to dismiss denied as to this theory.

defenses.defense: The complaint fails to plausibly allege that Meta possesses monopoly power or that the relevant market is properly defined.
defenses.legal_basis: Rule 12(b)(6) failure to state a claim; substantive antitrust pleading standards for monopoly power and market definition under the Sherman Act.

defenses.defense: Meta’s conduct, including its use of AI and machine learning in advertising products, reflects lawful competition and product improvement, not exclusionary or anticompetitive behavior.
defenses.legal_basis: Antitrust law’s protection of competition, not competitors; characterization of conduct as procompetitive and lawful under Sections 1 and 2 of the Sherman Act.

defenses.defense: The complaint does not adequately allege anticompetitive effects or a causal connection between Meta’s challenged practices and any injury to advertisers.
defenses.legal_basis: Antitrust injury and causation requirements under federal antitrust law; Rule 12(b)(6) pleading standards.

case_id: 2025-07-14_USCOURTS-cand-3_23-cv-00201_Andersen et al v. Stability AI Ltd. et al.pdf
case_name: Andersen et al v. Stability AI Ltd. et al
ai_relevance: Dispute over disclosure of AI image generation source code and related confidential technical materials to an expert in generative AI, raising competitive risk concerns.
ai_presence: The case concerns “highly confidential materials, including source code related to AI image generation models.” The expert at issue, Dr. Ben Yanbin Zhao, is described as “an academic researcher specializing in generative AI” who “has developed tools that could impact the defendants' AI models.” The defendants argue that disclosure of their “highly confidential materials” and “source code related to AI image generation models” to Dr. Zhao would create a “competitive risk” and “potential risk of competitive harm.” The court agrees, holding that “the risk of competitive harm to the defendants from disclosing their highly confidential materials to Dr. Zhao outweighs the plaintiffs' need for his expertise,” and therefore bars disclosure of those AI-related confidential materials to him.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individuals bringing copyright-related claims
parties.defendant_description: AI companies behind image generation models

claims.claim: Plaintiffs seek to disclose defendants’ highly confidential materials, including AI image generation source code and related technical information, to their expert, Dr. Ben Yanbin Zhao, for use in this litigation.
claims.legal_basis: Request under the protective order and discovery rules to designate Dr. Zhao as a qualified expert recipient of “highly confidential” materials; argument that his expertise in generative AI is necessary for plaintiffs to prosecute their claims.
claims.outcome: Denied. The court held that the competitive risk to defendants from disclosing highly confidential AI source code and related materials to Dr. Zhao outweighs plaintiffs’ need for his assistance, and therefore barred disclosure to him.

defenses.defense: Disclosure of highly confidential AI source code and related technical materials to Dr. Zhao would create an unacceptable risk of competitive harm because he develops tools and research that could affect or be used against defendants’ AI models in the marketplace or future work.
defenses.legal_basis: Protective order standards and Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 26(c) governing protective measures for trade secrets and confidential commercial information; balancing of need for discovery against risk of competitive harm.
defenses.defense_outcome: Accepted. The court agreed that the risk of competitive harm outweighed plaintiffs’ need and granted defendants’ request to prevent disclosure to Dr. Zhao.

case_id: 2025-08-21_USCOURTS-cand-4_24-cv-01454_Nazemian et al v. NVIDIA Corporation.pdf
case_name: Nazemian et al. v. NVIDIA Corporation
ai_relevance: Dispute over using copyrighted books in training NVIDIA’s NeMo Megatron large language models built on AI/ML.
ai_presence: Plaintiffs allege that NVIDIA Corporation committed copyright infringement by using their copyrighted books, included in publicly available large datasets like "The Pile," for training its NeMo Megatron large language models. The case involves AI as the dispute centers around the unauthorized use of copyrighted works to train large language models, which are AI-based systems designed to generate and manipulate human language. The court allowed discovery limited to exploring NVIDIA’s use of "The Pile" dataset to train its NeMo Megatron language models, including models beyond the four specifically mentioned in the original complaint, because the term "family" used by NVIDIA was not clearly defined.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual authors alleging copyright infringement
parties.defendant_description: Technology corporation developing AI language models

claims.claim: Copyright infringement by using plaintiffs’ copyrighted books contained in the dataset "The Pile" to train NeMo Megatron large language models without authorization.
claims.legal_basis: Federal copyright law (unauthorized reproduction and use of copyrighted works in training AI models).
claims.outcome: On the discovery motion, the court partially granted plaintiffs’ request, allowing discovery into whether NVIDIA used "The Pile" to train any NeMo Megatron models beyond those initially identified; ultimate merits of the copyright claim not yet decided.

claims.claim: Request for expanded discovery into NVIDIA’s use of "The Pile" to train additional NeMo Megatron models beyond the four models specifically named in the complaint.
claims.legal_basis: Federal civil procedure rules governing discovery relevance and proportionality.
claims.outcome: Court granted discovery limited to exploring NVIDIA’s use of "The Pile" for any NeMo Megatron models, including models beyond the four specifically mentioned, due to ambiguity in NVIDIA’s use of the term "family" of models.

defenses.defense: Limitation of discovery to only the four specifically identified NeMo Megatron models, based on NVIDIA’s characterization of those models as a single "family."
defenses.legal_basis: Federal civil procedure principles limiting discovery to clearly defined, relevant scope and resisting overbroad or burdensome discovery requests.

case_id: 2022-04-26_USCOURTS-ded-1_20-cv-00613_Thomson Reuters Enterprise Centre GmbH et al v. ROSS Intelligence Inc..pdf
case_name: Thomson Reuters Enterprise Centre GmbH et al. v. ROSS Intelligence Inc.
ai_relevance: Dispute centers on ROSS’s AI-powered legal research tool trained using plaintiffs’ content and plaintiffs’ use of their legal search platform to maintain market power.
ai_presence: The case involves ROSS Intelligence’s use of artificial intelligence to develop a competing legal research/search tool. ROSS allegedly used AI and machine-learning techniques to train its system on legal content derived from Thomson Reuters’ Westlaw database. Plaintiffs claim this AI-based tool infringed their copyrights and improperly leveraged their proprietary legal research materials. ROSS, in turn, alleges that plaintiffs used their dominant legal research platform and related tools to unlawfully tie access to public law and legal search functionality, thereby excluding AI-driven competitors like ROSS from the market.

parties.plaintiff_description: Corporate legal research and publishing businesses
parties.defendant_description: Technology company offering AI legal research tool

claims.claim: Copyright infringement against ROSS for using Westlaw content to develop its legal research tool.
claims.legal_basis: Federal copyright law (Copyright Act).
claims.outcome: Not resolved in this motion; case proceeds on plaintiffs’ core infringement claims (motion at issue concerned ROSS’s counterclaims).

claims.claim: Tortious interference with contractual relations based on ROSS’s alleged inducement of Westlaw licensees to breach their contracts by providing content or access for ROSS’s use.
claims.legal_basis: State law tortious interference with contract.
claims.outcome: Not resolved in this motion; underlying tortious interference claims by plaintiffs remain pending (motion addressed ROSS’s counterclaims).

claims.claim: Antitrust claim for unlawful tying—alleging plaintiffs tied their legal search tool to their database of public law, forcing customers to purchase both and excluding competitors like ROSS.
claims.legal_basis: Section 1 of the Sherman Act (tying arrangement / unreasonable restraint of trade).
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied in part; court allowed ROSS’s tying-based Section 1 claim to proceed as plausibly alleged, at least as to certain tying theories and markets.

claims.claim: Antitrust claim for monopolization and attempted monopolization—alleging plaintiffs used tying and other exclusionary conduct to maintain and extend monopoly power in legal research markets.
claims.legal_basis: Section 2 of the Sherman Act (monopolization and attempted monopolization).
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied in part; court allowed ROSS’s Section 2 claims premised on tying and related exclusionary conduct to proceed as plausibly alleged.

claims.claim: Antitrust claim based on sham litigation—alleging plaintiffs’ copyright and related lawsuits against ROSS were objectively baseless and intended to stifle competition.
claims.legal_basis: Section 2 of the Sherman Act (sham litigation as exclusionary conduct; Noerr-Pennington exception).
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss granted; court dismissed ROSS’s sham litigation-based antitrust claims for failure to plead specific, plausible facts showing the suits were objectively baseless.

claims.claim: Unfair competition claim alleging plaintiffs engaged in anticompetitive and unfair business practices to maintain dominance in legal research and suppress ROSS’s competing AI tool.
claims.legal_basis: State and/or federal unfair competition law (e.g., common law and related statutes, as pled by ROSS).
claims.outcome: Granted in part and denied in part; to the extent the unfair competition claim overlapped with viable tying-based antitrust theories, it was allowed to proceed; to the extent it relied on sham litigation, it was dismissed.

claims.claim: Antitrust conspiracy claim alleging plaintiffs and related entities agreed to restrain trade and exclude ROSS and similar competitors from the legal research market.
claims.legal_basis: Section 1 of the Sherman Act (conspiracy in restraint of trade).
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied in part; conspiracy allegations tied to the tying scheme and market exclusion were allowed to proceed as plausibly alleged, while any portion premised solely on sham litigation failed with the sham litigation theory.

defenses.defense: Plaintiffs’ lawsuits are protected petitioning activity and not sham litigation, thus immune from antitrust liability.
defenses.legal_basis: Noerr-Pennington doctrine and its sham litigation exception under antitrust law.

defenses.defense: ROSS failed to plausibly allege that the litigation was objectively baseless or brought without probable cause.
defenses.legal_basis: Pleading standards under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6) and Supreme Court sham litigation precedents (e.g., Professional Real Estate Investors).

defenses.defense: ROSS did not adequately define relevant product and geographic markets or show anticompetitive effects for some antitrust theories.
defenses.legal_basis: Substantive antitrust law under Sherman Act §§ 1 and 2, including market definition and market power requirements.

defenses.defense: Plaintiffs’ conduct constitutes lawful exercise of intellectual property rights and legitimate business practices, not unlawful tying or exclusionary conduct.
defenses.legal_basis: IP rights under copyright law and antitrust principles recognizing lawful exploitation of IP absent improper tying or coercion.

case_id: 2025-02-11_USCOURTS-ded-1_20-cv-00613_Thomson Reuters Enterprise Centre GmbH et al v. ROSS Intelligence Inc..pdf
case_name: Thomson Reuters Enterprise Centre GmbH et al v. ROSS Intelligence Inc.
ai_relevance: Defendant used AI-based legal research tool trained on plaintiffs’ Westlaw headnotes, making AI training central to the copyright dispute.
ai_presence: ROSS, seeking to train its legal AI tool, allegedly used Westlaw’s copyrighted headnotes obtained indirectly. The case significantly involves AI, as ROSS utilized AI technology to develop its legal research tool using the infringing content.

parties.plaintiff_description: Corporate owner of Westlaw legal research platform
parties.defendant_description: Company developing AI-based legal research tool

claims.claim: Direct copyright infringement based on copying and using Westlaw headnotes to develop and train ROSS’s legal research product.
claims.legal_basis: Copyright Act – unauthorized reproduction and use of copyrighted headnotes from Westlaw.
claims.outcome: Court granted partial summary judgment for Thomson Reuters, holding ROSS directly infringed plaintiffs’ copyrights in the headnotes, subject only to a remaining factual issue about any expired copyrights for trial.

claims.claim: Declaratory and related relief enforcing Thomson Reuters’ exclusive rights in Westlaw headnotes against ROSS’s use in its AI tool.
claims.legal_basis: Copyright Act exclusive rights (17 U.S.C. §§ 106 et seq.) and associated equitable remedies.
claims.outcome: Liability for infringement established on summary judgment; scope and any issues tied to potentially expired copyrights left for trial.

defenses.defense: Fair use – ROSS claimed its use of Westlaw headnotes to train an AI legal research tool was transformative and permissible.
defenses.legal_basis: 17 U.S.C. § 107 fair use doctrine (transformative use, purpose, nature, amount, and market effect).

defenses.defense: Challenge to validity or scope of copyrights in certain headnotes due to expiration of copyright terms.
defenses.legal_basis: Copyright Act limitations and duration provisions; works with expired copyrights enter the public domain.

case_id: 2024-09-27_USCOURTS-ded-1_20-cv-00613_Thomson Reuters Enterprise Centre GmbH et al v. ROSS Intelligence Inc..pdf
case_name: Thomson Reuters Enterprise Centre GmbH et al. v. ROSS Intelligence Inc.
ai_relevance: Dispute centers on ROSS’s AI-based legal research/search tool allegedly built using Thomson Reuters’ legal database; antitrust counterclaims challenge tying of database and search platform that hindered competing AI tools.
ai_presence: The case involves “a competing AI-based search tool” developed by ROSS Intelligence. Thomson Reuters alleged that ROSS used Thomson Reuters’ legal database to train and develop this AI-based legal search product. ROSS’s counterclaims asserted that Thomson Reuters’ tying of its legal search tool with its legal database made it difficult for competitors, including ROSS’s AI-based search tool, to enter and compete in the legal research market.

parties.plaintiff_description: Corporate provider of legal research databases and tools
parties.defendant_description: Company developing AI-based legal research/search tools

claims.claim: Copyright infringement based on ROSS’s use of Thomson Reuters’ legal database to develop a competing legal research/search product.
claims.legal_basis: Federal copyright law (alleged unauthorized copying and use of Thomson Reuters’ protected database content).
claims.outcome: Not resolved in the provided summary; the described decision addresses only ROSS’s antitrust counterclaims, not final disposition of Thomson Reuters’ copyright claims.

claims.claim: Antitrust counterclaim alleging illegal tying of Thomson Reuters’ legal search tool with its legal database, foreclosing competition from independent search tools like ROSS’s AI product.
claims.legal_basis: Federal antitrust law, including tying doctrine under Section 1 of the Sherman Act and/or Section 3 of the Clayton Act (requiring proof of separate products and properly defined relevant markets).
claims.outcome: Court granted summary judgment in favor of Thomson Reuters; ROSS’s tying-based antitrust counterclaims were dismissed for failure to show separate products or adequately define relevant markets.

defenses.defense: ROSS’s antitrust counterclaims fail because Thomson Reuters’ legal database and search tool are not separate products capable of being tied.
defenses.legal_basis: Antitrust tying doctrine requires distinct products; absence of separate demand defeats tying claim.

defenses.defense: ROSS failed to define cognizable relevant product and geographic markets for its antitrust tying theory.
defenses.legal_basis: Antitrust law requires properly defined relevant markets to establish market power and competitive harm; failure of market definition warrants summary judgment.

case_id: 2025-03-06_USCOURTS-cand-3_24-cv-07919_Brightex Bio-Photonics_ LLC v. L_Oreal USA_ Inc..pdf
case_name: Brightex Bio-Photonics, LLC v. L'Oreal USA, Inc.
ai_relevance: Case concerns a patented system using facial image analysis and automated recommendations to provide personalized skincare treatments, involving advanced image processing and algorithmic assessment of skin characteristics.
ai_presence: The summary describes the '358 Patent as involving an invention for providing personalized skincare recommendations using facial analysis. It notes that the involvement of AI/machine learning appears in the advanced image analysis for identifying skin characteristics and recommending treatments, but the court found this implementation too generic and abstract as claimed, insufficient to supply an inventive concept under Section 101.

parties.plaintiff_description: Company asserting skincare analysis patents
parties.defendant_description: Cosmetics and skincare corporation

claims.claim: Patent infringement of the ’358 Patent relating to a system for providing personalized skincare recommendations using facial analysis.
claims.legal_basis: 35 U.S.C. § 271 (patent infringement) based on alleged unauthorized use of the patented skincare recommendation technology.
claims.outcome: Dismissed with prejudice; the court held the asserted claims of the ’358 Patent are patent-ineligible under 35 U.S.C. § 101 and therefore cannot be infringed.

claims.claim: Patent infringement of a second Brightex patent (in addition to the ’358 Patent) asserted against L’Oreal.
claims.legal_basis: 35 U.S.C. § 271 (patent infringement) based on alleged unauthorized use of technology covered by the second patent.
claims.outcome: Dismissed with prejudice; the court found the asserted claims of the second patent likewise invalid under 35 U.S.C. § 101 as directed to an abstract idea without an inventive concept.

defenses.defense: The asserted claims of the ’358 Patent are invalid because they are directed to an abstract idea—recommending skincare treatments based on the severity of skin characteristics—and therefore are not patent-eligible subject matter.
defenses.legal_basis: 35 U.S.C. § 101; Supreme Court’s Alice framework for determining patent eligibility of abstract ideas implemented on a computer.
defenses.defense_outcome: Accepted; the court agreed the claims are directed to an abstract idea and lack an inventive concept, rendering them patent-ineligible and invalid.

defenses.defense: Any alleged use of facial analysis and recommendation technology by L’Oreal merely implements generic computer and image-processing functions, which cannot supply an inventive concept to transform an abstract idea into patent-eligible subject matter.
defenses.legal_basis: 35 U.S.C. § 101; Alice step two requiring an inventive concept beyond generic computer implementation.
defenses.defense_outcome: Accepted; the court held that the claimed use of advanced image analysis and recommendation algorithms was too generic and conventional to constitute an inventive concept.

case_id: 2024-09-30_USCOURTS-ded-1_19-cv-01410_VB Assets_ LLC v. Amazon.com Services LLC.pdf
case_name: VB Assets, LLC v. Amazon.com Services LLC
ai_relevance: Dispute centers on Amazon Alexa smart speaker voice-assistant technology allegedly infringing patents.
ai_presence: The case involves Amazon’s Alexa smart speaker technology, a voice-controlled digital assistant that uses automated, algorithmic processing of speech and commands. The patents at issue relate to smart speaker technology implemented in Alexa-enabled devices, and the alleged infringement arises from Alexa’s operation and features.

parties.plaintiff_description: Patent-holding business entity asserting smart speaker patents.
parties.defendant_description: Amazon subsidiary operating Alexa smart speaker products.

claims.claim: Willful infringement of patents related to smart speaker technology by Amazon’s Alexa products.
claims.legal_basis: Federal patent infringement under 35 U.S.C. §§ 271 et seq., including willful infringement for enhanced damages.
claims.outcome: Jury found Amazon willfully infringed certain claims of four asserted patents and awarded $46.7 million in damages; the court upheld the infringement and willfulness findings for three patents but set aside the jury’s finding of infringement as to one patent claim for insufficient evidence.

claims.claim: Entitlement to monetary damages for past infringement, including reasonable royalty or lost profits.
claims.legal_basis: Patent damages provisions under 35 U.S.C. § 284.
claims.outcome: Jury awarded VB Assets $46.7 million in damages for past infringement; the court largely upheld the award consistent with its ruling that one patent claim lacked sufficient evidence of infringement.

claims.claim: Entitlement to ongoing royalty for post-verdict infringement by continued Alexa sales and use.
claims.legal_basis: Equitable and legal relief under 35 U.S.C. § 283–284 for future use of patented technology instead of or in addition to an injunction.
claims.outcome: Court granted VB Assets an ongoing royalty and ordered further briefing to determine the appropriate royalty rate.

claims.claim: Entitlement to pre-judgment and post-judgment interest on the damages award.
claims.legal_basis: 35 U.S.C. § 284 and applicable federal law on interest in patent cases.
claims.outcome: Court granted VB Assets pre- and post-judgment interest, with calculation details to follow consistent with the judgment.

defenses.defense: Non-infringement of the asserted patent claims by Alexa products.
defenses.legal_basis: Substantive patent law under 35 U.S.C. § 271, arguing accused Alexa functionalities do not practice the asserted claim limitations.
defenses.defense_outcome: Partially successful; the court found insufficient evidence to support the jury’s infringement finding for one patent claim and overturned that portion, but upheld the jury’s infringement findings for the remaining three patents.

defenses.defense: Challenge to sufficiency of the evidence supporting the jury’s infringement and willfulness findings and damages award (post-trial motions).
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rules of Civil Procedure 50 and 59 (JMOL and new trial), and patent law standards for willfulness and damages.
defenses.defense_outcome: Partially successful; the court agreed there was insufficient evidence for one patent claim and set aside that part of the verdict, but otherwise upheld the jury’s findings of infringement, willfulness, and the bulk of the damages award.

case_id: 2025-06-23_USCOURTS-cand-3_24-cv-05417_Bartz et al v. Anthropic PBC.pdf
case_name: Bartz et al v. Anthropic PBC
ai_relevance: Dispute over using copyrighted books to train Anthropic’s large language model, Claude, and whether such AI training is fair use under copyright law.
ai_presence: "the AI company Anthropic for copyright infringement, claiming that the company had illegally used their books to train its large language model (LLM), Claude. Anthropic had accumulated a vast digital library by both purchasing and illegally downloading millions of books, using these works to train AI models. The court granted summary judgment in favor of Anthropic, finding that using the books to train the AI was transformative and constituted fair use under Section 107 of the Copyright Act, but denied such judgment for the pirated copies retained in Anthropic's central library. ... The main legal issue is whether Anthropic's use of copyrighted books to train its AI models constitutes 'fair use' under Section 107 of the Copyright Act, particularly considering the books were acquired, in part, through piracy and were used to develop a highly profitable AI service. ... The court held that the use of the books to train AI models was a fair use due to its transformative nature, as the AI was creating novel outputs and not directly competing with the authors' works. ... Imagine Anthropic is like a giant robotic student that reads a lot of books to learn how to write like humans. This robot read a bunch of books, including ones it didn’t legally pay for, to get really good at writing text."

parties.plaintiff_description: Group of authors alleging copyright infringement
parties.defendant_description: Artificial intelligence company operating Claude LLM

claims.claim: Anthropic infringed plaintiffs’ copyrights by using their books, without authorization, to train its large language model Claude.
claims.legal_basis: Copyright infringement under the Copyright Act, including 17 U.S.C. §§ 106 and 501; fair use limitation under 17 U.S.C. § 107 at issue.
claims.outcome: Court granted summary judgment for Anthropic on this use, holding that using the books to train AI models was transformative and constituted fair use under § 107.

claims.claim: Anthropic infringed copyrights by acquiring and retaining pirated copies of plaintiffs’ books in its central digital library.
claims.legal_basis: Copyright infringement under the Copyright Act, including unauthorized reproduction and retention of pirated copies; fair use defense disputed under 17 U.S.C. § 107.
claims.outcome: Court denied summary judgment in Anthropic’s favor as to the pirated copies retained in its central library; whether this retention is infringing remains for trial.

defenses.defense: Use of plaintiffs’ books to train AI models is fair use because it is highly transformative and does not substitute for or directly compete with the original works.
defenses.legal_basis: Fair use doctrine under 17 U.S.C. § 107, emphasizing transformative purpose and limited market harm.
defenses.outcome: Accepted in part; court held that training the AI on the books is fair use and granted summary judgment for Anthropic on that aspect.

defenses.defense: Retention of pirated copies in Anthropic’s central library is also protected as fair use.
defenses.legal_basis: Fair use doctrine under 17 U.S.C. § 107, applied to storage and retention of copies.
defenses.outcome: Not resolved in Anthropic’s favor at summary judgment; court denied summary judgment on this issue, leaving the legality of retaining pirated copies for trial.

case_id: 2021-09-30_USCOURTS-nynd-1_18-cv-00549_Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute et al. v. Amazon.com_ Inc..pdf
case_name: Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute et al. v. Amazon.com, Inc.
ai_relevance: Dispute over patented natural language interface technology allegedly used in Amazon Alexa, involving automated natural language processing and query interpretation systems.
ai_presence: The case centers on a patent covering a "natural language interface (NLI)" technology and a "natural language query (NLQ) processor" that processes natural language inputs. The patent describes a method for processing natural language inputs using an NLQ processor, which has applications in products like Amazon Alexa. The plaintiffs allege that Amazon’s products, including Alexa, use this natural language interface technology in a way that infringes the asserted patent. The court’s opinion focuses on construing disputed claim terms in the ’798 Patent that define how the natural language interface and natural language query processor interpret and respond to user queries.

parties.plaintiff_description: University and affiliated patent-holding company
parties.defendant_description: Large e-commerce and technology corporation

claims.claim: Patent infringement of the ’798 Patent relating to a natural language interface (NLI) and natural language query (NLQ) processor technology allegedly practiced by Amazon products such as Alexa.
claims.legal_basis: Federal patent law under 35 U.S.C. §§ 271 et seq. for infringement of a duly issued United States patent (the ’798 Patent).
claims.outcome: In this claim construction decision, the court did not decide ultimate infringement or liability, but construed the disputed terms of the ’798 Patent claims, issuing specific interpretations that will govern subsequent infringement and validity determinations.

defenses.defense: Non‑infringement: Amazon contends that its accused products do not practice the asserted claims as properly construed, because the disputed claim terms should be interpreted more narrowly or differently than plaintiffs propose.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal patent law principles of claim construction under Markman and related Federal Circuit precedent; 35 U.S.C. § 271 (no infringement if accused products do not meet all properly construed claim limitations).

defenses.defense: Claim construction limiting scope of the ’798 Patent: Amazon argues for specific constructions of disputed terms in the ’798 Patent (e.g., how the natural language interface and natural language query processor must operate) that would restrict the patent’s coverage and thereby avoid or narrow infringement.
defenses.legal_basis: Judicial claim construction under Markman v. Westview Instruments and subsequent Federal Circuit case law governing intrinsic and extrinsic evidence in interpreting patent claims.

case_id: 2011-08-18_USCOURTS-njd-2_04-cv-03623_SYNCSORT INCORPORATED v. INNOVATIVE ROUTINES INTERNATIONAL INC
case_name: Syncsort Incorporated v. Innovative Routines International, Inc.
ai_relevance: NOT RELATED

parties.plaintiff_description: Software corporation providing data transformation tools
parties.defendant_description: Software corporation, maker of CoSORT product

claims.claim: Misappropriation of trade secrets in Syncsort’s command language and related materials to develop the ssu2scl translator utility.
claims.legal_basis: State trade secret law (misappropriation of trade secrets).
claims.outcome: Court held Syncsort’s command language is a trade secret and found IRI misappropriated it; injunctive relief granted barring use or distribution of ssu2scl and requiring destruction of related materials.

claims.claim: Unfair competition by using Syncsort’s confidential reference materials and job-control scripts to facilitate customer migration to IRI’s CoSORT software.
claims.legal_basis: State unfair competition law/common law unfair competition.
claims.outcome: Court found IRI’s conduct constituted unfair competition; injunctive relief granted prohibiting further use and distribution of the translator and derivative materials.

defenses.defense: Syncsort’s command language and related information were not protectable trade secrets (e.g., publicly known or readily ascertainable).
defenses.legal_basis: Trade secret law requirements of secrecy and independent economic value.

defenses.defense: Development of the ssu2scl translator was based on legitimate reverse engineering or independent development, not misappropriation.
defenses.legal_basis: Permissible reverse engineering/independent development doctrines under trade secret law.

defenses.defense: IRI’s conduct did not amount to unfair competition because it was lawful competitive behavior.
defenses.legal_basis: Common law unfair competition standards requiring wrongful or improper means.

case_id: 2019-04-01_USCOURTS-cand-5_18-cv-07233_WeRide Corp. et al v. Huang et al.pdf
case_name: WeRide Corp. et al. v. Kun Huang et al.
ai_relevance: Dispute centers on autonomous vehicle software and technology using AI algorithms.
ai_presence: The case involves WeRide Corp., an autonomous vehicle company, alleging misappropriation of its software and technology for autonomous vehicles. The defendants’ competing companies, Zhong Zhi Xing Technology Co. Ltd. (ZZX) and AllRide.AI, Inc., are alleged to have used WeRide’s confidential and proprietary autonomous driving software and related technology, which rely on artificial intelligence and machine learning for self-driving functionality.

parties.plaintiff_description: Autonomous vehicle technology companies
parties.defendant_name: Kun Huang, Jing Wang, ZZX, AllRide.AI
parties.defendant_description: Former employees and competing AV companies

claims.claim: Misappropriation of trade secrets under the Defend Trade Secrets Act (DTSA) against Kun Huang, ZZX, and AllRide.AI
claims.legal_basis: Federal Defend Trade Secrets Act, 18 U.S.C. § 1836 et seq.
claims.outcome: Court found WeRide likely to succeed and granted preliminary injunction against Huang, ZZX, and AllRide, ordering them to cease use and disclosure of WeRide’s confidential and trade secret information and allowing expedited discovery.

claims.claim: Misappropriation of trade secrets under the California Uniform Trade Secrets Act (CUTSA) against Kun Huang, ZZX, and AllRide.AI
claims.legal_basis: California Uniform Trade Secrets Act, Cal. Civ. Code § 3426 et seq.
claims.outcome: Court found WeRide likely to succeed and granted preliminary injunction against Huang, ZZX, and AllRide, prohibiting use or disclosure of WeRide’s trade secrets and permitting expedited discovery.

claims.claim: Misappropriation of trade secrets under DTSA and/or CUTSA against Jing Wang
claims.legal_basis: Defend Trade Secrets Act and California Uniform Trade Secrets Act
claims.outcome: Court denied preliminary injunction as to Wang on trade secret claims because WeRide did not show a likelihood of success on the merits.

claims.claim: Breach of contract (e.g., confidentiality, non-disclosure, and related employment agreements) against Kun Huang
claims.legal_basis: California contract law based on Huang’s employment and confidentiality agreements with WeRide
claims.outcome: Court’s preliminary injunction relied in part on Huang’s contractual obligations; injunction granted restricting Huang’s use and disclosure of WeRide’s confidential information, indicating WeRide showed likelihood of success on related contract theories.

claims.claim: Breach of contract (employment and confidentiality obligations) against Jing Wang
claims.legal_basis: California contract law based on Wang’s executive/employment agreements with WeRide
claims.outcome: Court did not extend preliminary injunctive relief against Wang on trade secret and related claims, finding WeRide had not demonstrated a likelihood of success sufficient to justify an injunction against Wang at this stage.

claims.claim: Defamation by Jing Wang against WeRide
claims.legal_basis: California defamation law (libel/slander)
claims.outcome: Court denied preliminary injunction on the defamation claim against Wang because WeRide failed to demonstrate a likelihood of success on the merits of that claim.

claims.claim: Related unfair competition and business tort claims (e.g., unfair competition, interference) against Huang, ZZX, and AllRide.AI
claims.legal_basis: California Unfair Competition Law and common-law business tort principles
claims.outcome: While the order focused on trade secret misappropriation, the court’s partial grant of preliminary injunction against Huang, ZZX, and AllRide was premised on WeRide’s strong showing on trade secret-related theories; broader business tort claims were not separately enjoined beyond the trade secret-based relief.

defenses.defense: No misappropriation of trade secrets; defendants independently developed their autonomous driving technology
defenses.legal_basis: Rebuttal to DTSA and CUTSA elements requiring acquisition, disclosure, or use of trade secrets by improper means.

defenses.defense: Information at issue is not a trade secret because it is generally known or readily ascertainable
defenses.legal_basis: Challenge to DTSA and CUTSA definition of trade secret, arguing lack of secrecy or independent economic value from secrecy.

defenses.defense: WeRide failed to show likelihood of success or irreparable harm necessary for preliminary injunction
