defenses.legal_basis: Federal preliminary injunction standard under Winter v. NRDC and related Ninth Circuit precedent.

defenses.defense: Jing Wang did not personally misappropriate any WeRide trade secrets
defenses.legal_basis: Liability under DTSA and CUTSA requires proof of Wang’s acquisition, disclosure, or use of trade secrets by improper means; defendants argue absence of such conduct.

defenses.defense: Statements attributed to Jing Wang were not defamatory or were protected
defenses.legal_basis: California defamation law defenses, including truth, opinion, and lack of requisite fault or damages.

case_id: 2024-07-09_USCOURTS-med-2_24-cv-00121_WEX INC v. HP INC et al.pdf
case_name: WEX Inc. v. HP Inc. et al.
ai_relevance: Both parties’ software products use artificial intelligence and automated analytics for data insights, making AI-enabled platforms central to the disputed “WEX” branding and to the likelihood-of-confusion analysis.
ai_presence: The summary explains that “AI and automated systems are involved in the contested software and in WEX Inc.'s services, as both use AI for data insights and analytics, though in different business domains.” This indicates that HP’s “Workforce Experience Platform” software incorporates AI and automated systems, and WEX Inc.’s services likewise use AI for data insights and analytics, even though they operate in different sectors.

parties.plaintiff_description: Corporation providing technology and payment services
parties.defendant_description: Technology corporation offering software products

claims.claim: Trademark infringement based on HP’s use of the “WEX” mark for its Workforce Experience Platform software, allegedly causing consumer confusion with WEX Inc.’s existing trademarks.
claims.legal_basis: Federal and/or state trademark infringement law, including likelihood of confusion under trademark statutes and common law.
claims.outcome: Court found WEX Inc. likely to succeed on the merits and granted a preliminary injunction restraining HP from using the “WEX” mark in connection with its software pending final resolution.

claims.claim: Unfair competition and related trademark-based harm arising from HP’s use of the “WEX” name, allegedly diluting WEX Inc.’s brand and misleading consumers about source, sponsorship, or affiliation.
claims.legal_basis: Unfair competition principles under trademark and related state/federal law (e.g., Lanham Act § 43(a) and analogous state law).
claims.outcome: Court’s preliminary injunction, based on likely success on trademark infringement and risk of consumer confusion and irreparable harm, effectively restrains HP’s use of “WEX,” providing interim relief on the unfair competition theory as well.

defenses.defense: HP’s use of “WEX” for its Workforce Experience Platform does not create a likelihood of consumer confusion with WEX Inc.’s marks because the products and business domains differ.
defenses.legal_basis: Trademark law standards for likelihood of confusion, arguing dissimilarity of goods/services, channels of trade, and consumer perception.

defenses.defense: Any harm to WEX Inc. from HP’s use of “WEX” is speculative or not irreparable, so a preliminary injunction should not issue.
defenses.legal_basis: Equitable standards for preliminary injunctions, including irreparable harm and balance of hardships.

case_id: 2024-05-20_USCOURTS-ded-1_23-cv-00802_Staton Techiya_ LLC v. Harman International Industries_ Incorporated et al.pdf
case_name: Staton Techiya, LLC v. Harman International Industries, Inc., et al.
ai_relevance: Patents cover ear-worn tech using intelligent data processing and AI for sound personalization and management; dispute centers on alleged infringement of these AI-enabled audio technologies.
ai_presence: The case summary states that the patents involve "ear-worn technology innovations related to sound processing and personalized sound management that use intelligent data processing, including AI, as part of the patented technologies."

parties.plaintiff_description: Technology company holding ear-worn audio patents
parties.defendant_name: Harman International Industries, Inc.; Harman-Kardon, Inc.
parties.defendant_description: Audio electronics corporations accused of patent infringement

claims.claim: Direct infringement of nine patents covering ear-worn audio technology, including sound processing and personalized sound management features.
claims.legal_basis: 35 U.S.C. § 271(a) – direct patent infringement of asserted patents.
claims.outcome: Not resolved at this motion-to-dismiss stage; claims for direct infringement remain pending.

claims.claim: Pre-suit induced infringement of certain asserted patents by encouraging customers and others to use accused ear-worn products in infringing ways.
claims.legal_basis: 35 U.S.C. § 271(b) – induced infringement, based on alleged pre-suit knowledge of the patents and specific intent to cause infringement.
claims.outcome: Court held Techiya sufficiently pled pre-suit knowledge for some patents; motion to dismiss pre-suit induced infringement claims as to those patents denied, so those induced infringement claims proceed.

claims.claim: Post-suit induced infringement of the asserted patents based on Harman’s knowledge of the patents after the lawsuit was filed.
claims.legal_basis: 35 U.S.C. § 271(b) – induced infringement premised on post-suit knowledge via the complaint and continued alleged inducing conduct.
claims.outcome: Court granted Harman’s motion to dismiss post-suit induced infringement claims without prejudice, finding insufficient allegations of Harman’s post-suit knowledge and intent; Techiya is allowed to amend its complaint.

claims.claim: Pre-suit willful infringement of certain asserted patents, alleging Harman knew of the patents before suit and nonetheless infringed in a manner that was egregious or reckless.
claims.legal_basis: Willful infringement under 35 U.S.C. § 284 (enhanced damages), requiring pre-suit knowledge and egregious conduct.
claims.outcome: Court held Techiya adequately alleged pre-suit knowledge for some patents, making willful infringement claims for that pre-suit period plausible; motion to dismiss those pre-suit willfulness claims denied.

claims.claim: Post-suit willful infringement of the asserted patents, alleging Harman’s continued infringement after being notified by the filing of the complaint.
claims.legal_basis: Willful infringement under 35 U.S.C. § 284, based on post-suit knowledge from the complaint and continued infringing conduct.
claims.outcome: Court granted Harman’s motion to dismiss post-suit willful infringement claims without prejudice due to insufficient pleading of Harman’s post-suit knowledge and egregiousness; Techiya may replead.

defenses.defense: Insufficient pleading of Harman’s pre-suit knowledge of the asserted patents, defeating induced and willful infringement claims.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6) – failure to state a claim; knowledge and intent are required elements for induced and willful infringement.

defenses.defense: Insufficient pleading of Harman’s post-suit knowledge and intent regarding induced infringement, because mere filing of the complaint is not enough without additional factual allegations.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6); case law requiring plausible factual allegations of knowledge and specific intent for post-suit induced infringement.

defenses.defense: Insufficient pleading of post-suit willful infringement, including lack of detailed allegations of egregious conduct after Harman allegedly became aware of the patents.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6); willfulness standards under 35 U.S.C. § 284 and relevant Federal Circuit precedent requiring knowledge plus egregious or reckless behavior.

case_id: 2023-09-06_USCOURTS-ca5-22-50405_Rex Real Est I v. Rex Real Est.pdf
case_name: Rex Real Estate I, L.P. v. Rex Real Estate Exchange, Inc.
ai_relevance: Defendant uses AI-driven platform to connect home buyers with properties, relevant to branding and marketplace confusion.
ai_presence: The summary states that automation was relevant because the defendant, Rex Real Estate Exchange, Inc., uses AI to connect buyers with homes, indicating its real estate platform relies on artificial intelligence to match customers with properties.

parties.plaintiff_description: Texas real estate business and trademark user
parties.defendant_description: Real estate company using AI home-buying platform

claims.claim: Trademark infringement of federally registered 'Rex' trademarks under Section 32(1) of the Lanham Act.
claims.legal_basis: Lanham Act § 32(1) – infringement of registered trademarks.
claims.outcome: Dismissed for lack of standing; plaintiff failed to prove valid assignment of trademark rights from original owner.

claims.claim: Trademark infringement and unfair competition based on unregistered 'Rex' marks, including pre-registration use and associated goodwill.
claims.legal_basis: Lanham Act § 43(a) – infringement of unregistered marks and false designation of origin.
claims.outcome: Fifth Circuit reversed summary judgment and remanded; court held there may be protectable unregistered rights and factual disputes over secondary meaning and consumer confusion.

claims.claim: Likelihood of consumer confusion arising from defendant’s use of the name 'Rex' in real estate services.
claims.legal_basis: Lanham Act §§ 32(1) and 43(a) – likelihood of confusion standard for trademark infringement.
claims.outcome: As to registered marks under § 32(1), claim failed for lack of standing; as to unregistered marks under § 43(a), claim remanded for further proceedings on confusion and secondary meaning.

defenses.defense: Plaintiff lacks standing to sue for infringement of the federally registered 'Rex' trademarks because it never received a valid assignment of those marks.
defenses.legal_basis: Lanham Act § 32(1) requires ownership or valid assignment of the registered mark to have standing.

defenses.defense: Plaintiff’s asserted unregistered 'Rex' marks lack secondary meaning and therefore are not protectable trademarks.
defenses.legal_basis: Lanham Act § 43(a) protection for unregistered marks requires proof of distinctiveness or secondary meaning.

defenses.defense: Defendant’s use of 'Rex' does not create a likelihood of consumer confusion with plaintiff’s services.
defenses.legal_basis: Lanham Act likelihood-of-confusion standard for both registered and unregistered marks.

case_id: 2025-07-21_USCOURTS-cand-4_23-cv-03918_OpenAI_ Inc. v. Open Artificial Intelligence_ Inc. et al.pdf
case_name: OpenAI, Inc. v. Open Artificial Intelligence, Inc. et al.
ai_relevance: Dispute over trademark rights in the name of an AI company and products, involving artificial intelligence services branded as “OpenAI” and “Open AI.”
ai_presence: The case centers on OpenAI, Inc., a company providing artificial intelligence technologies and services, and Open Artificial Intelligence, Inc., led by Guy Ravine, which used the similar “Open AI” name for competing AI-related products. The court evaluated which party had a protectible trademark interest in the “OpenAI” / “Open AI” mark in connection with AI products and services, and found that OpenAI, Inc. had acquired secondary meaning in its AI-related mark before Ravine used the similar mark in commerce for competing AI offerings.

parties.plaintiff_description: Corporation providing artificial intelligence technologies and services.
parties.defendant_name: Open Artificial Intelligence, Inc.; Guy Ravine
parties.defendant_description: Competing AI business and its individual principal.

claims.claim: Trademark infringement under federal law for use of the “OpenAI” / “Open AI” mark on competing products and services.
claims.legal_basis: Federal trademark law (likely Lanham Act § 32/§ 43(a)) based on ownership of a protectible mark and likelihood of confusion.
claims.outcome: Court granted summary judgment for OpenAI, Inc., holding that OpenAI owned a protectible mark with secondary meaning before Ravine’s commercial use and that Ravine’s use infringed; judgment entered for OpenAI on its infringement claim.

claims.claim: Cancellation of Guy Ravine’s “Open AI” trademark registration.
claims.legal_basis: Lanham Act provisions allowing cancellation of registrations that conflict with prior rights or lack validity (e.g., 15 U.S.C. § 1119).
claims.outcome: Court ordered Ravine’s “Open AI” trademark registration canceled as part of the summary judgment in favor of OpenAI, Inc.

claims.claim: Permanent injunction barring defendants from using the “Open AI” mark or confusingly similar designations.
claims.legal_basis: Equitable relief under the Lanham Act upon a finding of trademark infringement and likelihood of ongoing confusion.
claims.outcome: Court permanently enjoined Guy Ravine and his company from using the “Open AI” mark in commerce for competing products and services.

claims.claim: Defendants’ counterclaims asserting their own trademark rights in “Open AI” and challenging OpenAI, Inc.’s rights.
claims.legal_basis: Lanham Act and related trademark principles, based on alleged prior rights or independent validity of Ravine’s “Open AI” mark.
claims.outcome: Court rejected Ravine’s counterclaims, finding he failed to prove a valid, protectible trademark interest due to lack of secondary meaning and exclusivity; judgment entered for OpenAI, Inc. on all counterclaims.

defenses.defense: Guy Ravine claimed he, not OpenAI, Inc., owned a valid trademark in “Open AI,” including via his own registration.
defenses.legal_basis: Trademark ownership principles under the Lanham Act, arguing priority and validity of his registered mark.

defenses.defense: Assertion that OpenAI, Inc. lacked a protectible trademark interest because its “OpenAI” mark had not acquired secondary meaning or distinctiveness at the relevant time.
defenses.legal_basis: Requirement that descriptive or non-inherently distinctive marks acquire secondary meaning to be protectible under federal trademark law.

defenses.defense: Argument that OpenAI, Inc. did not have exclusive use of the “OpenAI” / “Open AI” designation, undermining any claim of secondary meaning or enforceable rights.
defenses.legal_basis: Trademark law requirement of substantially exclusive and continuous use to establish secondary meaning and enforceable rights.

case_id: 2022-11-22_USCOURTS-txwd-6_21-cv-00968_Parus Holdings Inc. v. Apple Inc..pdf
case_name: Parus Holdings Inc. v. Apple Inc.
ai_relevance: Dispute involves Apple’s Siri, which uses machine learning and AI for speech recognition and natural language processing in voice-enabled internet search and retrieval systems allegedly covered by Parus’s patents.
ai_presence: The summary states that the case concerns “patents related to voice-enabled internet search and retrieval systems” and notes that “the use of Apple’s Siri involving machine learning and AI for speech recognition and natural language processing” is relevant. Siri is described as a voice-controlled system that relies on “machine learning and AI for speech recognition and natural language processing,” tying the accused technology to AI/ML methods used to interpret spoken commands and retrieve information from the internet.

parties.plaintiff_description: Corporate patent holder and technology company
parties.defendant_description: Large technology corporation, maker of Siri

claims.claim: Apple infringed multiple Parus patents covering voice-enabled internet search and retrieval systems used in products like Siri.
claims.legal_basis: Patent infringement under the U.S. Patent Act (35 U.S.C. §§ 271 et seq.).
claims.outcome: Not decided in this order; the court only ruled on Apple’s motion to transfer venue, leaving the infringement claims to be resolved in the Northern District of California.

claims.claim: The Western District of Texas is a proper and convenient venue for Parus’s patent infringement suit against Apple.
claims.legal_basis: Venue and convenience arguments under 28 U.S.C. § 1404(a), opposing transfer.
claims.outcome: Rejected; the court granted Apple’s motion and ordered transfer to the Northern District of California as a clearly more convenient forum.

defenses.defense: The case should be transferred to the Northern District of California because it is clearly a more convenient forum for parties and witnesses and better serves the interests of justice.
defenses.legal_basis: 28 U.S.C. § 1404(a) (change of venue for convenience of parties and witnesses and in the interest of justice).

defenses.defense: Most relevant witnesses, documents, and development activities for the accused Siri and related technologies are located in the Northern District of California, making Texas an inconvenient forum.
defenses.legal_basis: Convenience-of-witnesses and location-of-evidence factors under § 1404(a) jurisprudence.

case_id: 2023-08-03_USCOURTS-tnwd-2_22-cv-02838_Pritchard v. Thompson et al.pdf
case_name: Pritchard v. Thompson et al.
ai_relevance: Dispute over alleged misappropriation of patented dashcam design with AI capabilities used in defendants’ products.
ai_presence: The summary describes plaintiff’s invention as a “patented dashcam design with AI capabilities” and alleges defendants misappropriated this AI-enabled dashcam concept and used it in their products.

parties.plaintiff_description: Pro se individual inventor and patent holder
parties.defendant_description: Technology company and its representative

claims.claim: Misappropriation of trade secrets related to his patented AI-enabled dashcam design and associated confidential information disclosed for an anticipated NDA.
claims.legal_basis: Tennessee Uniform Trade Secrets Act (TUTSA) and related trade secret principles
claims.outcome: Dismissed; court found lack of personal jurisdiction over defendants and held that TUTSA governs the trade secret theory, preempting overlapping state-law claims.

claims.claim: State-law claims (such as fraud, misrepresentation, breach of implied contract, and similar tort or contract theories) based on inducing him to disclose confidential dashcam design details under the guise of preparing a Non-Disclosure Agreement.
claims.legal_basis: Tennessee common law tort and contract theories (e.g., fraud, misrepresentation, implied contract), all grounded in alleged misuse of trade secrets.
claims.outcome: Recommended for dismissal as preempted by the Tennessee Uniform Trade Secrets Act because they rely on the same nucleus of facts as the trade secret misappropriation claim and also subject to dismissal for lack of personal jurisdiction.

claims.claim: Intellectual property/patent-related claim that defendants used his patented dashcam design with AI capabilities in their products without authorization.
claims.legal_basis: Federal patent and intellectual property principles as referenced by plaintiff’s allegation of a “patented” design (exact statutory basis not specified in summary).
claims.outcome: Recommended for dismissal due to lack of personal jurisdiction over defendants; court did not reach the merits of any patent infringement theory.

defenses.defense: The court lacks personal jurisdiction because defendants did not purposefully avail themselves of conducting activities in Tennessee and have insufficient contacts with the forum.
defenses.legal_basis: Due process limits on personal jurisdiction under the U.S. Constitution and applicable federal and Tennessee jurisdictional standards.

defenses.defense: Plaintiff’s non-TUTSA state-law claims are preempted because they are based on the same alleged trade secret misappropriation as his TUTSA claim.
defenses.legal_basis: Preemption provision of the Tennessee Uniform Trade Secrets Act (TUTSA), which displaces conflicting tort, restitutionary, and other state-law claims based on trade secret misuse.

case_id: 2024-06-24_USCOURTS-tnmd-3_23-cv-01092_Concord Music Group_ Inc. et al v. Anthropic PBC.pdf
case_name: Concord Music Group, Inc. et al. v. Anthropic PBC
ai_relevance: AI company Anthropic allegedly used copyrighted song lyrics to train its Claude AI model without permission, leading to a copyright infringement dispute and jurisdictional challenge.
ai_presence: The case centers on Anthropic PBC, described as an AI company that develops and operates an artificial intelligence model called Claude. Plaintiffs allege Anthropic used copyrighted song lyrics to train its AI model, Claude, without authorization. The court’s summary explains that the dispute arises from the way Anthropic’s AI model learns from and uses copyrighted material, specifically song lyrics, to enhance its capabilities. The opinion discusses Anthropic’s limited activities and contacts in Tennessee in connection with offering and operating its AI services, concluding those contacts are insufficient to establish personal jurisdiction in the Middle District of Tennessee. The case is transferred to the Northern District of California, where Anthropic has its principal place of business and where its AI operations are based.

parties.plaintiff_name: Concord Music Group, Inc. et al.
parties.plaintiff_description: Group of music publishing companies
parties.defendant_description: Artificial intelligence technology company

claims.claim: Copyright infringement based on Anthropic’s alleged use of plaintiffs’ song lyrics to train and operate the Claude AI model without authorization.
claims.legal_basis: Federal copyright law (17 U.S.C. §§ 101 et seq.).
claims.outcome: Not adjudicated on the merits; case dismissed in the Middle District of Tennessee for lack of personal jurisdiction and improper venue and transferred to the Northern District of California.

claims.claim: Contributory and/or vicarious copyright infringement arising from Anthropic’s AI system allegedly reproducing or distributing plaintiffs’ lyrics in response to user prompts.
claims.legal_basis: Federal copyright law doctrines of contributory and vicarious infringement.
claims.outcome: Not adjudicated on the merits; action transferred to the Northern District of California after dismissal for lack of personal jurisdiction in Tennessee.

claims.claim: Related state and/or federal unfair competition or similar claims tied to Anthropic’s alleged unauthorized use of song lyrics to develop and commercialize its AI model.
claims.legal_basis: Unspecified in the summary; likely state unfair competition or analogous statutes accompanying the copyright claims.
claims.outcome: Not adjudicated on the merits; included in the case that was dismissed for lack of personal jurisdiction and transferred to the Northern District of California.

defenses.defense: Lack of personal jurisdiction in the Middle District of Tennessee because Anthropic’s contacts with Tennessee are insufficient to establish minimum contacts.
defenses.legal_basis: Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment; Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(2); personal jurisdiction jurisprudence requiring minimum contacts and fairness.

defenses.defense: Improper venue in the Middle District of Tennessee given Anthropic’s principal place of business and more substantial connections in the Northern District of California.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal venue statutes, including 28 U.S.C. § 1391, and transfer provisions under 28 U.S.C. § 1406(a) or § 1404(a).

case_id: 2024-08-02_USCOURTS-cand-3_22-cv-07197_La Canada Ventures_ Inc. v. MDalgorithms_ Inc..pdf
case_name: La Canada Ventures, Inc. v. MDalgorithms, Inc.
ai_relevance: Defendant uses AI-driven technology to customize skincare products; court notes AI use did not contribute to trademark confusion or false advertising.
ai_presence: The summary states that the case "involved the use of AI technology by MDalgorithms to customize skincare products" and that "the court noted that this did not contribute to confusion between the products."

parties.plaintiff_description: Corporate business selling beauty products
parties.defendant_description: Corporation offering AI-based acne treatments

claims.claim: Trademark infringement based on defendant’s use of the "MDacne" mark allegedly infringing plaintiff’s trademarks and causing consumer confusion.
claims.legal_basis: Federal trademark law (Lanham Act) and related trademark infringement doctrines.
claims.outcome: Court granted partial summary judgment for MDalgorithms; found insufficient evidence of likelihood of consumer confusion, so the trademark infringement claim failed.

claims.claim: False advertising related to MDalgorithms’ marketing and advertising claims about its "MDacne" products and services.
claims.legal_basis: Federal and California false advertising laws, including the Lanham Act and California state law.
claims.outcome: Court granted partial summary judgment for MDalgorithms; found no material factual dispute showing MDalgorithms’ advertising claims were false or misleading, so the false advertising claim failed.

claims.claim: Trademark cancellation of the "MDacne" mark based on alleged infringement and confusion.
claims.legal_basis: Trademark cancellation provisions tied to validity of the "MDacne" mark under federal trademark law.
claims.outcome: Claim failed because it was dependent on the success of the trademark infringement and false advertising claims, which were resolved in MDalgorithms’ favor.

defenses.defense: No likelihood of consumer confusion between plaintiff’s marks and defendant’s "MDacne" mark.
defenses.legal_basis: Lanham Act trademark infringement standards requiring proof of likelihood of confusion.

defenses.defense: Advertising statements about "MDacne" were not false or misleading and did not constitute false advertising.
defenses.legal_basis: Lanham Act and California false advertising law standards requiring proof of falsity or misleadingness and materiality.

defenses.defense: Plaintiff’s expert evidence on confusion and advertising impact was unreliable and inadmissible.
defenses.legal_basis: Evidentiary rules governing expert testimony and methodology (e.g., Daubert-type reliability requirements).

case_id: 2023-03-15_USCOURTS-mad-1_20-cv-12236_Findability Sciences_ Inc. v. Soft10_ Inc..pdf
case_name: Findability Sciences, Inc. v. Soft10, Inc.
ai_relevance: Dispute centers on alleged unauthorized use and sublicensing of Soft10’s AI-related software, Dr. Mo, by AI company Findability Sciences under software licensing and services agreements.
ai_presence: The case involves Findability Sciences, described as an AI company, and Soft10’s software product called “Dr. Mo,” which is characterized as AI-related software. The dispute concerns whether Findability Sciences unlawfully used, integrated, and sublicensed this AI-related Dr. Mo software to its own customers, and whether such use exceeded or violated the scope of the parties’ software agreements, including licensing, payment, and sublicensing terms.

parties.plaintiff_description: Artificial intelligence technology company and licensee
parties.defendant_description: Software company, owner of Dr. Mo

claims.claim: Copyright infringement based on Findability’s alleged unauthorized use, copying, and sublicensing of the Dr. Mo software.
claims.legal_basis: Federal copyright law (17 U.S.C. § 101 et seq.).
claims.outcome: Findability’s motion for summary judgment on this counterclaim denied; claim proceeds to trial due to genuine disputes of material fact.

claims.claim: Breach of contract for violating the terms of the software and related agreements governing use, payment, and sublicensing of Dr. Mo.
claims.legal_basis: State contract law under the parties’ written software and services agreements.
claims.outcome: Findability’s motion for summary judgment on this counterclaim denied; breach of contract claim proceeds to trial because material factual disputes remain.

claims.claim: Violation of the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing in connection with performance of the software agreements.
claims.legal_basis: State common law duty implied in every contract (implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing).
claims.outcome: Findability’s motion for summary judgment on this counterclaim denied; claim proceeds to trial due to disputed facts about the parties’ conduct and expectations.

claims.claim: Unfair or deceptive business practices related to the software relationship and sublicensing of Dr. Mo.
claims.legal_basis: Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 93A (unfair and deceptive acts and practices).
claims.outcome: Findability’s motion for summary judgment on this Chapter 93A counterclaim denied; claim proceeds to trial because factual disputes preclude summary judgment.

claims.claim: Misappropriation of trade secrets relating to confidential aspects of the Dr. Mo software and associated information.
claims.legal_basis: Trade secret law (likely Massachusetts trade secret statute and/or common law).
claims.outcome: Findability’s motion for summary judgment on this counterclaim denied; misappropriation claim proceeds to trial due to genuine issues of material fact.

claims.claim: Promissory estoppel based on alleged promises outside or beyond the written contracts regarding use or commercialization of Dr. Mo.
claims.legal_basis: State common law doctrine of promissory estoppel (reliance on extra-contractual promises).
claims.outcome: Summary judgment granted in favor of Findability; promissory estoppel counterclaim dismissed because existing contracts govern the relationship and/or evidence of a separate enforceable promise is lacking.

claims.claim: Unjust enrichment for benefits Findability allegedly received from using and sublicensing Dr. Mo without proper compensation.
claims.legal_basis: State common law of unjust enrichment and quasi-contract.
claims.outcome: Summary judgment granted in favor of Findability; unjust enrichment counterclaim dismissed as preempted or barred by the existence of express contracts covering the same subject matter.

claims.claim: Rescission of the parties’ agreements concerning Dr. Mo based on alleged misconduct or failure of consideration.
claims.legal_basis: Equitable remedy of rescission under state contract law.
claims.outcome: Summary judgment granted in favor of Findability; rescission counterclaim dismissed due to insufficient legal and factual basis to unwind the contracts.

claims.claim: Conversion based on alleged wrongful control over or interference with Soft10’s Dr. Mo software and related property rights.
claims.legal_basis: State common law tort of conversion.
claims.outcome: Summary judgment granted in favor of Findability; conversion counterclaim dismissed as preempted by federal copyright law and/or duplicative of contract and copyright claims.

defenses.defense: Existence of valid, enforceable contracts governing the parties’ rights and obligations regarding Dr. Mo, barring quasi-contract claims such as promissory estoppel and unjust enrichment.
defenses.legal_basis: Contract law principle that express contracts preclude quasi-contractual recovery for the same subject matter.

defenses.defense: Federal copyright preemption of state-law claims like conversion and certain unjust enrichment theories based on rights equivalent to copyright.
defenses.legal_basis: 17 U.S.C. § 301 preemption of state-law claims equivalent to exclusive rights under copyright.

defenses.defense: Lack of sufficient evidence to support elements of promissory estoppel, unjust enrichment, rescission, and conversion.
defenses.legal_basis: Summary judgment standard under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 56 requiring absence of genuine dispute of material fact and failure of proof on essential elements.

defenses.defense: Genuine disputes of material fact regarding scope of license, authorization, and performance, requiring trial on copyright infringement, breach of contract, implied covenant, Chapter 93A, and trade secret claims rather than judgment as a matter of law.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 56; standard for denying summary judgment when material facts are disputed.

case_id: 2020-10-19_USCOURTS-ded-1_19-cv-00524_VoterLabs_ Inc. v. Ethos Group Consulting Services_ LLC.pdf
case_name: VoterLabs, Inc. v. Ethos Group Consulting Services, LLC
ai_relevance: Dispute involves alleged misuse and funding of machine learning / AI software development VoterLabs claimed to be building, and whether work on that AI-related solution was properly within the Ethos engagement or secretly for other projects.
ai_presence: The summary states: "AI and machine learning are part of the dispute, as VoterLabs claimed to work on a machine learning solution seemingly related to separate projects that Ethos alleged were funded under the guise of work for Ethos." It also notes "some mysterious AI software VoterLabs said they were secretly working on" as part of the disagreement over how investment and development funds were used.

parties.plaintiff_description: Corporate software / technology company
parties.defendant_description: Consulting services business entity

claims.claim: Malicious breach of contract based on Ethos’ failure to make the engagement payment and alleged use of that nonpayment as leverage to extract concessions from VoterLabs.
claims.legal_basis: State contract law governing breach of contract and the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing (malicious breach).
claims.outcome: Ethos’ motion to dismiss this malicious breach of contract claim was denied; the claim remains pending.

claims.claim: Breach of contract for failure to timely make the engagement payment owed under the parties’ agreement.
claims.legal_basis: State contract law for nonperformance of contractual payment obligations.
claims.outcome: Not resolved in the described order; the court’s ruling focused on the malicious breach claim and counterclaims, leaving the basic breach claim in place.

claims.claim: Fraud by VoterLabs in allegedly misrepresenting the intended use of Ethos’ investment and the nature and purpose of the software and machine learning development work.
claims.legal_basis: State common-law fraud (intentional misrepresentation) relating to inducement and performance of the engagement agreement.
claims.outcome: Ethos’ motion for leave to amend its counterclaim to add this fraud claim was granted; the fraud counterclaim may proceed as amended.

claims.claim: Negligent misrepresentation by VoterLabs regarding how Ethos’ funds would be used and whether the software and machine learning solution were being developed for Ethos rather than for separate projects.
claims.legal_basis: State common-law negligent misrepresentation (duty to provide accurate information in a business transaction).
claims.outcome: Ethos’ motion for leave to amend its counterclaim to add this negligent misrepresentation claim was granted; the negligent misrepresentation counterclaim may proceed as amended.

defenses.defense: VoterLabs’ malicious breach of contract claim fails to state a claim because Ethos’ withholding of the engagement payment was not malicious and did not constitute a separate actionable wrong beyond ordinary breach.
defenses.legal_basis: Rule 12(b)(6) failure to state a claim under applicable contract law standards for malicious or bad-faith breach.
defenses.defense_outcome: The court rejected this defense at the pleading stage by denying Ethos’ motion to dismiss the malicious breach of contract claim.

defenses.defense: VoterLabs allegedly misrepresented the intended use of Ethos’ investment and the nature of the software and machine learning work, diverting funds to separate AI-related projects; therefore VoterLabs’ own misconduct bars or reduces its contract recovery.
defenses.legal_basis: Affirmative defenses grounded in fraud and negligent misrepresentation principles, pled as counterclaims under state law.
defenses.defense_outcome: The court allowed Ethos to assert these theories by granting leave to amend its counterclaim to add fraud and negligent misrepresentation, permitting these defenses/counterclaims to go forward.

case_id: 2022-06-29_USCOURTS-mad-1_22-cv-10656_Nuance Communications_ Inc. v. Kovalenko.pdf
case_name: Nuance Communications, Inc. v. Kovalenko
ai_relevance: Dispute involves competing AI-powered radiology products; concern over misuse of AI-related confidential information and technology.
ai_presence: The case summary states that Nuance’s products, including the Precision Imaging Network, use AI algorithms integrated into radiology workflows. It further explains that Sirona offers competing AI-powered solutions, which led Nuance to fear that Kovalenko’s work for Sirona could expose or misuse Nuance’s confidential information related to these AI-driven technologies.

parties.plaintiff_description: Technology corporation providing AI radiology solutions
parties.defendant_description: Individual former employee of Nuance

claims.claim: Breach of non-compete agreement by joining a direct competitor, Sirona Medical, Inc.
claims.legal_basis: Contract law – enforcement of restrictive covenant/non-compete clause in employment agreement
claims.outcome: Court found Nuance likely to succeed on the merits and granted a preliminary injunction barring Kovalenko from working for Sirona in a conflicting role.

claims.claim: Threatened misuse or disclosure of Nuance’s confidential information and trade secrets related to its AI-powered radiology products.
claims.legal_basis: Contractual confidentiality obligations and trade secret protection principles under state law
claims.outcome: Court agreed there was a substantial risk of misuse of confidential information and relied on this risk in granting the preliminary injunction.

defenses.defense: Her employment at Sirona does not violate the non-compete because Sirona is not a direct competitor or her role does not overlap with Nuance’s business.
defenses.legal_basis: Contract interpretation of scope and enforceability of non-compete clause.

defenses.defense: Her work at Sirona would not use or disclose Nuance’s confidential information or trade secrets.
defenses.legal_basis: Trade secret and confidentiality law principles limiting injunctions to actual or likely misuse, not mere employment alone.

case_id: 2024-02-12_USCOURTS-cand-3_23-cv-03416_Silverman et al v. OpenAI_ Inc. et al.pdf
case_name: Silverman et al. v. OpenAI, Inc. et al.
ai_relevance: Plaintiffs allege OpenAI used their copyrighted books without permission to train and operate AI language models, including ChatGPT, raising questions about AI training data, outputs, and related unfair competition.
ai_presence: The case centers on OpenAI’s development and operation of AI language models, including ChatGPT. Plaintiffs allege that OpenAI copied their copyrighted books in full and ingested them into training datasets to train large language models. The complaint asserts that these AI models learn from and rely on the expressive content of plaintiffs’ works to generate text outputs, and that OpenAI’s business model involves providing public access to these AI systems via products such as ChatGPT. The court’s order discusses whether the training and operation of these AI models, and the way they were allegedly trained on copyrighted books without consent, can support claims for copyright infringement, violations of the DMCA, negligence, unjust enrichment, and unfair competition under California’s Unfair Competition Law. The court ultimately dismisses most claims but allows the UCL “unfair” prong claim, based on OpenAI’s alleged unfair use of copyrighted books to train its AI models, to proceed.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual authors in putative class action
parties.defendant_description: AI company and related corporate entities

claims.claim: Direct copyright infringement based on use of plaintiffs’ books to train OpenAI’s AI language models and to generate outputs.
claims.legal_basis: Federal Copyright Act, 17 U.S.C. § 101 et seq.
claims.outcome: Not described as ruled on in the provided summary; the order discussed in the summary focuses on vicarious infringement and other ancillary claims, so the disposition of direct infringement is not specified here.

claims.claim: Vicarious copyright infringement for allegedly profiting from and having the right and ability to control infringing uses of plaintiffs’ works by OpenAI’s AI models and services.
claims.legal_basis: Federal Copyright Act, 17 U.S.C. § 101 et seq. (vicarious liability doctrine).
claims.outcome: Dismissed on OpenAI’s motion to dismiss for failure to sufficiently allege the required elements of vicarious infringement; plaintiffs granted leave to amend to attempt to cure deficiencies.

claims.claim: Violation of the Digital Millennium Copyright Act for removal or alteration of copyright management information associated with plaintiffs’ works in the course of training and operating OpenAI’s AI models.
claims.legal_basis: Digital Millennium Copyright Act (DMCA), 17 U.S.C. § 1202 and related provisions.
claims.outcome: Dismissed on OpenAI’s motion to dismiss because plaintiffs failed to adequately plead the necessary factual basis and elements; plaintiffs given an opportunity to amend their DMCA claims.

claims.claim: Negligence based on OpenAI’s alleged failure to exercise reasonable care in acquiring, handling, and using plaintiffs’ copyrighted books to train AI models and in deploying those models.
claims.legal_basis: Common-law negligence under applicable state law (duty, breach, causation, damages).
claims.outcome: Dismissed on OpenAI’s motion to dismiss for failure to state a claim, including insufficient allegations of a cognizable duty and other elements; plaintiffs allowed leave to amend.

claims.claim: Unjust enrichment based on OpenAI’s alleged receipt and retention of benefits from using plaintiffs’ copyrighted works to train and commercialize AI models without compensating plaintiffs.
claims.legal_basis: Equitable unjust enrichment / restitution under state law.
claims.outcome: Dismissed on OpenAI’s motion to dismiss; the court found the unjust enrichment theory insufficient as pleaded but allowed plaintiffs an opportunity to amend their complaint.

claims.claim: Unfair competition based on allegedly unfair business practices in using copyrighted books without consent to train and commercialize AI models, thereby gaining an unfair advantage over authors and competitors.
claims.legal_basis: California Unfair Competition Law (UCL), Cal. Bus. & Prof. Code § 17200, “unfair” prong.
claims.outcome: OpenAI’s motion to dismiss denied as to the UCL “unfair” prong; the court held plaintiffs adequately alleged unfair practices, so this claim is allowed to proceed.

defenses.defense: Failure to state a claim for vicarious copyright infringement because plaintiffs did not adequately allege OpenAI’s right and ability to supervise infringing activity or a direct financial benefit from specific infringements.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6); substantive standards for vicarious copyright liability under the Copyright Act.

defenses.defense: Failure to state a claim under the DMCA because plaintiffs did not plausibly allege removal or alteration of copyright management information with the requisite scienter or connection to infringement.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6); 17 U.S.C. § 1202 requirements for DMCA CMI claims.

defenses.defense: Failure to state a negligence claim because OpenAI owed no cognizable legal duty to plaintiffs in the manner alleged, and plaintiffs did not sufficiently plead breach, causation, or legally cognizable damages.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6); state common-law negligence elements.

defenses.defense: Failure to state an unjust enrichment claim because the theory is either not an independent cause of action or is inadequately pleaded, including lack of a direct benefit conferred by plaintiffs on OpenAI.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6); state law on unjust enrichment and restitution.

defenses.defense: Insufficient allegations of unfairness under the UCL, arguing that plaintiffs did not show substantial consumer injury, violation of established public policy, or unfair conduct tethered to a legislatively declared policy.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6); California Unfair Competition Law standards for the “unfair” prong.

case_id: 2023-04-03_USCOURTS-mad-1_22-cv-11708_Groma_ LLC v. BuildRE_ LLC et al.pdf
case_name: Groma, LLC v. BuildRE, LLC et al.
ai_relevance: One defendant, Groma GPS-Turkey, designs AI-based vehicle automation software, but AI technology is incidental; the dispute and ruling concern trademark infringement and personal jurisdiction, not AI use or harms.
ai_presence: The case summary notes that “one defendant, Groma GPS-Turkey, designs software using AI for vehicle automation,” identifying that entity’s business activities. No other portions of the decision analyze or rely on AI; the AI reference is limited to describing that defendant’s software products.

parties.plaintiff_description: Massachusetts-based business entity alleging trademark infringement
parties.defendant_description: Texas and Turkey-based business entities, including Groma GPS-Turkey

claims.claim: Trademark infringement against BuildRE, LLC and related entities for use of the Groma mark or similar branding.
claims.legal_basis: Federal and/or state trademark law (e.g., Lanham Act) as asserted by plaintiff.
claims.outcome: Dismissed without reaching merits because the court found no personal jurisdiction over the Texas and Turkey-based defendants in Massachusetts.

claims.claim: Request for preliminary injunction to stop defendants’ alleged infringing use of the Groma-related marks during the litigation.
claims.legal_basis: Equitable injunctive relief under trademark and federal procedural law.
claims.outcome: Denied as moot because the court lacked personal jurisdiction and dismissed the action, making injunctive relief unavailable.

defenses.defense: Lack of personal jurisdiction in Massachusetts due to insufficient contacts with the forum (no offices, employees, or meaningful business there).
defenses.legal_basis: Constitutional due process limits on personal jurisdiction and applicable Massachusetts long-arm statute standards.
defenses.defense_outcome: Accepted; the court agreed it lacked personal jurisdiction and dismissed the case.

case_id: 2017-08-29_USCOURTS-cand-3_17-cv-03049_Purepredictive_ Inc. v. H20.AI_ Inc..pdf
case_name: PurePredictive, Inc. v. H2O.AI, Inc.
ai_relevance: Patent concerns an automated predictive analytics factory using machine learning to automatically generate predictive models.
ai_presence: The summary explains that U.S. Patent No. 8,880,446 "relates to an automated predictive analytics factory." It further notes: "The use of artificial intelligence and machine learning is central to the patent as it involves automating the creation of predictive models." The court characterizes the claims as directed to "mathematical algorithms for predictive analytics" implemented on a computer, rejecting them as patent-ineligible abstract ideas under 35 U.S.C. § 101.

parties.plaintiff_description: Corporation offering predictive analytics technology
parties.defendant_description: Corporation providing machine learning software

claims.claim: Patent infringement of U.S. Patent No. 8,880,446 related to an automated predictive analytics factory.
claims.legal_basis: 35 U.S.C. § 271 (patent infringement) based on alleged unauthorized use of the ’446 Patent.
claims.outcome: Dismissed with prejudice on Rule 12(b)(6) motion; court held all asserted claims of the ’446 Patent are directed to patent-ineligible subject matter under 35 U.S.C. § 101 and therefore cannot be infringed.

defenses.defense: The asserted patent claims are directed to abstract ideas involving mathematical algorithms and predictive analytics, implemented on generic computer components, and are therefore not patent-eligible.
defenses.legal_basis: 35 U.S.C. § 101 (patent-eligible subject matter); Alice/Mayo two-step framework for determining abstract ideas and lack of inventive concept.

defenses.defense: Complaint fails to state a claim upon which relief can be granted because the patent is invalid under § 101, so no plausible infringement claim exists.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6) (failure to state a claim).

case_id: 2025-03-25_USCOURTS-cand-5_24-cv-03811_Concord Music Group_ Inc. et al v. Anthropic PBC.pdf
case_name: Concord Music Group, Inc. et al. v. Anthropic PBC
ai_relevance: Dispute over Anthropic’s Claude AI models allegedly trained on copyrighted song lyrics without licenses, and AI outputs reproducing those lyrics.
ai_presence: The case centers on Anthropic’s artificial intelligence model, Claude. Plaintiffs allege that Anthropic trained its Claude AI models on copyrighted song lyrics owned or administered by the music publishers without authorization or licenses. They contend that Claude can output or reproduce substantial portions of those lyrics in response to user prompts, and that Anthropic’s ingestion and use of the lyrics in training datasets, as well as the model’s outputs, infringe their copyrights. The requested preliminary injunction sought to stop Anthropic from using plaintiffs’ lyrics in training its AI models and from distributing models that can reproduce those lyrics. The court’s decision addresses whether the alleged use of copyrighted lyrics in AI training and AI-generated outputs causes irreparable harm sufficient to justify preliminary injunctive relief.

parties.plaintiff_name: Concord Music Group, Inc. et al.
parties.plaintiff_description: Music publishers and rights holders
parties.defendant_description: Artificial intelligence company developing Claude models

claims.claim: Copyright infringement based on Anthropic’s use of plaintiffs’ song lyrics to train its Claude AI models without authorization or license.
claims.legal_basis: Federal copyright law, including 17 U.S.C. §§ 106 et seq. (exclusive rights in copyrighted works).
claims.outcome: No final merits ruling at this stage; court denied plaintiffs’ motion for a preliminary injunction because they failed to show a likelihood of irreparable harm pending resolution of the case.

claims.claim: Copyright infringement based on Claude’s reproduction and display of plaintiffs’ copyrighted lyrics in response to user prompts.
claims.legal_basis: Federal copyright law, including 17 U.S.C. §§ 106(1), 106(3), and 106(5) (rights to reproduce, distribute, and publicly display).
claims.outcome: No final merits ruling; request to preliminarily enjoin Anthropic from distributing or operating models that can output plaintiffs’ lyrics was denied for lack of demonstrated irreparable harm.

claims.claim: Request for preliminary injunction to bar Anthropic from using plaintiffs’ copyrighted lyrics in training datasets and to require removal or segregation of such lyrics from existing models and systems.
claims.legal_basis: Equitable remedy under federal law for alleged ongoing copyright infringement; standards for preliminary injunction (likelihood of success, irreparable harm, balance of equities, public interest).
claims.outcome: Court denied the preliminary injunction, holding that plaintiffs did not establish a likelihood of irreparable harm and therefore were not entitled to immediate injunctive relief before a full adjudication on the merits.

defenses.defense: Plaintiffs have not shown a likelihood of irreparable harm from Anthropic’s continued use of the lyrics in AI training or model operation.
defenses.legal_basis: Equitable standard for preliminary injunction under federal law (e.g., Winter v. NRDC) requiring proof of likely irreparable harm.

defenses.defense: Any alleged harms are compensable by money damages and thus not irreparable.
defenses.legal_basis: Injunction doctrine under federal copyright and general equitable principles that monetary remedies can preclude a finding of irreparable harm.

defenses.defense: Uncertainty regarding the extent to which Claude’s training on copyrighted lyrics or its outputs actually displace plaintiffs’ markets or licensing opportunities.
defenses.legal_basis: Preliminary injunction standard requiring concrete, non-speculative evidence of likely harm; burden on movant to show more than conjectural injury.

case_id: 2024-08-14_USCOURTS-ded-1_24-cv-00084_Samsara Inc. v. Motive Technologies Inc..pdf
case_name: Samsara Inc. v. Motive Technologies, Inc.
ai_relevance: Dispute involves AI-driven dashboard camera technology allegedly infringed and misappropriated.
ai_presence: "The dispute includes claims about AI technology related to Samsara's AI-driven dashboard cameras."

parties.plaintiff_description: Delaware corporation, tech company
parties.defendant_description: Delaware corporation, technology company

claims.claim: Patent infringement relating to Samsara’s technology, including AI-driven dashboard cameras.
claims.legal_basis: Federal patent law (35 U.S.C. et seq.).
claims.outcome: Not decided on the merits in this opinion; case transferred to the Northern District of California under 28 U.S.C. § 1404(a).

claims.claim: Misappropriation of Samsara’s proprietary technology.
claims.legal_basis: Trade secret and related proprietary rights law (likely state and/or federal).
claims.outcome: Not decided on the merits in this opinion; case transferred to the Northern District of California under 28 U.S.C. § 1404(a).

claims.claim: Opposition to Motive’s motion to transfer venue from Delaware to the Northern District of California.
claims.legal_basis: 28 U.S.C. § 1404(a) (plaintiff’s preference for chosen forum).
claims.outcome: Denied; the court granted Motive’s motion and ordered transfer to the Northern District of California.

defenses.defense: The case should be transferred to the Northern District of California because the parties, witnesses, events, and relevant state laws are centered there.
defenses.legal_basis: 28 U.S.C. § 1404(a) (convenience of parties and witnesses and interest of justice).

case_id: 2016-02-29_USCOURTS-cand-4_15-cv-00798_Loop AI Labs_ Inc. v. Gatti et al.pdf
case_name: Loop AI Labs Inc. v. Gatti et al.
ai_relevance: Dispute centers on alleged theft and misuse of Loop AI Labs’ artificial intelligence technology and related trade secrets by its former CEO and associated entities.
ai_presence: Loop AI Labs Inc. is described as a startup developing AI technology, and the alleged trade secrets at issue in the litigation are tied to this AI technology. The summary notes that the case “showcas[es] the involvement of AI through Loop's technology being a core aspect of the trade secrets discussed.”

parties.plaintiff_description: Artificial intelligence technology startup company
parties.defendant_description: Former CEO and related business entities

claims.claim: Misappropriation of trade secrets related to Loop’s AI technology and associated confidential business information.
claims.legal_basis: Trade secret misappropriation under applicable state and/or federal trade secret law (e.g., California trade secret law).
claims.outcome: Underlying claim not resolved in this order; court’s ruling concerns discovery only. Court allowed Loop to obtain some third‑party documents via subpoenas, with narrowed time frames and scope, and denied other portions as overbroad or insufficiently justified.

claims.claim: Related business tort and contract claims arising from alleged misuse of Loop’s confidential information and competitive wrongdoing by Gatti and associated entities.
claims.legal_basis: State law business torts and contract principles (e.g., breach of duty, unfair competition), as referenced in connection with trade secret allegations.
claims.outcome: Substantive merits not decided in this order; court partially granted and partially denied Loop’s motion to enforce third‑party subpoenas to obtain evidence relevant to these claims.

defenses.defense: Objection that the third‑party subpoenas sought irrelevant information not reasonably calculated to lead to admissible evidence.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal discovery rules limiting discovery to relevant, proportional information (Fed. R. Civ. P. 26, 45).

defenses.defense: Objection that the subpoenas were overbroad and unduly burdensome in scope and time period.
defenses.legal_basis: Protections against undue burden and overbreadth in subpoenas under Fed. R. Civ. P. 26 and 45.

defenses.defense: Privacy objections to production of personal and financial records, including phone and banking information, for Gatti and related entities.
defenses.legal_basis: Privacy rights and protections recognized under federal and state law, applied through Rule 26 proportionality and Rule 45 protections.

case_id: 2020-05-15_USCOURTS-azd-2_19-cv-04685_Modulus Financial Engineering Incorporated v. Modulus Data USA Incorporated et al.pdf
case_name: Modulus Financial Engineering Incorporated v. Modulus Data USA Incorporated et al.
ai_relevance: NOT RELATED

parties.plaintiff_description: Corporation providing financial and software-related services
parties.defendant_name: Modulus Data USA & Modulus Data, Inc.
parties.defendant_description: Corporate defendants accused of trademark infringement

claims.claim: Federal trademark infringement based on defendants’ use of Modulus-related marks
claims.legal_basis: Lanham Act trademark infringement provisions (15 U.S.C. §§ 1114, 1125)
claims.outcome: Dismissed without prejudice for lack of personal jurisdiction; court did not reach merits

claims.claim: Unfair competition arising from alleged confusingly similar use of Modulus marks
claims.legal_basis: Lanham Act § 43(a) and related unfair competition principles
claims.outcome: Dismissed without prejudice for lack of personal jurisdiction; court did not reach merits

claims.claim: Cancellation of defendants’ trademark registrations incorporating Modulus-related marks
claims.legal_basis: Lanham Act provisions allowing cancellation of registered marks (15 U.S.C. § 1119)
claims.outcome: Dismissed without prejudice for lack of personal jurisdiction; court did not reach merits

defenses.defense: Lack of personal jurisdiction in Arizona federal court
defenses.legal_basis: Due Process Clause and personal jurisdiction standards (minimum contacts, purposeful direction, and fairness)

case_id: 2020-06-25_USCOURTS-mad-1_19-cv-12551_Singular Computing LLC v. Google LLC.pdf
case_name: Singular Computing LLC v. Google LLC
ai_relevance: Patents cover specialized low-precision, high-dynamic-range arithmetic useful for AI workloads.
ai_presence: The summary explains that Singular’s patented methods of processing using Compact Arithmetic Processing Elements are designed to perform low precision and high dynamic range (LPHDR) arithmetic operations, which improve how computers handle tasks like artificial intelligence. It notes: “Imagine Singular Computing created a new way for computers to do math, allowing them to do it faster and with fewer parts. They got patents for these methods, believing this would improve how computers handle tasks like artificial intelligence.”

parties.plaintiff_description: Technology company holding processing patents
parties.defendant_description: Large technology corporation and service provider

claims.claim: Patent infringement of Singular’s patents covering methods of processing using Compact Arithmetic Processing Elements that perform low precision and high dynamic range arithmetic operations.
claims.legal_basis: 35 U.S.C. § 271 (patent infringement) and related patent rights in methods of processing using Compact Arithmetic Processing Elements.
claims.outcome: Ongoing; at this stage, the court denied Google’s motion to dismiss, allowing Singular’s infringement claims based on the asserted patents to proceed.

claims.claim: That the asserted patents claim patent-eligible subject matter and are not directed merely to unpatentable abstract ideas.
claims.legal_basis: 35 U.S.C. § 101 (patent-eligible subject matter).
claims.outcome: At the motion-to-dismiss stage, the court agreed that Singular plausibly alleged that the patents incorporate inventive concepts beyond abstract ideas and therefore refused to dismiss on § 101 grounds.

defenses.defense: The asserted patents are directed to abstract ideas and therefore claim ineligible subject matter that cannot be patented.
defenses.legal_basis: 35 U.S.C. § 101; abstract idea doctrine under Alice/Mayo framework.
defenses.defense_outcome: The court rejected this argument at the motion-to-dismiss stage, holding it could not conclude the claims were ineligible as a matter of law and denying Google’s motion to dismiss.

case_id: 2021-06-08_USCOURTS-cand-3_20-cv-09148_People.ai_ Inc. v. SetSail Technologies_ Inc..pdf
case_name: People.ai, Inc. v. SetSail Technologies, Inc.
ai_relevance: Dispute centers on patents covering data analytics and CRM systems that involve machine learning used in sales and customer relationship management software.
ai_presence: The summary states that the asserted patents are "related to data analytics and CRM systems that involve machine learning." The case concerns whether SetSail’s software products infringe these machine-learning-related patents by using similar data analytics and CRM functionalities.

parties.plaintiff_description: Corporation providing AI-driven sales and CRM analytics software.
parties.defendant_description: Corporation offering sales performance and analytics software products.

claims.claim: Direct patent infringement of People.ai’s patents by SetSail’s software products.
claims.legal_basis: 35 U.S.C. § 271 for infringement of patents related to data analytics and CRM systems involving machine learning.
claims.outcome: Dismissed on motion to dismiss; court held complaint lacked sufficient factual allegations showing how SetSail’s software met specific elements of the asserted patent claims.

claims.claim: Indirect and/or contributory infringement of the asserted patents (implied from patent suit).
claims.legal_basis: 35 U.S.C. § 271(b)–(c), based on alleged use and promotion of infringing software functionalities.
claims.outcome: Effectively dismissed with the complaint; insufficient factual detail to plausibly allege infringement under any theory.

defenses.defense: Complaint fails to state a claim for patent infringement because it does not plausibly allege how SetSail’s products practice each element of the asserted patent claims.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6); pleading standards under Twombly and Iqbal requiring plausible, fact-based allegations of infringement.

case_id: 2025-03-26_USCOURTS-cand-5_24-cv-03811_Concord Music Group_ Inc. et al v. Anthropic PBC.pdf
case_name: Concord Music Group, Inc. et al. v. Anthropic PBC
ai_relevance: Dispute over Anthropic’s AI model Claude allegedly training on and outputting copyrighted song lyrics without permission, raising questions about AI training data and secondary copyright liability.
ai_presence: The case centers on Anthropic’s AI system, Claude. Plaintiffs allege that Anthropic used their copyrighted song lyrics to train Claude’s language models without authorization and that Claude can output those lyrics, allegedly infringing their copyrights. The court’s summary discusses “Anthropic’s AI, Claude,” its training on potentially copyrighted material, and its use and distribution of songs in a way plaintiffs claim constitutes contributory and vicarious infringement, as well as alleged removal of copyright management information under the DMCA.

parties.plaintiff_name: Concord Music Group, Inc. et al.
parties.plaintiff_description: Music publishing companies and rights holders
parties.defendant_description: Artificial intelligence company developing Claude model

claims.claim: Secondary copyright infringement – contributory infringement based on Claude’s use and output of plaintiffs’ song lyrics.
claims.legal_basis: Copyright Act, contributory infringement doctrine (secondary liability).
claims.outcome: Dismissed on motion to dismiss for failure to allege specific acts of direct third‑party infringement and insufficient allegations that Anthropic knew of and materially contributed to such infringement; dismissal with leave to amend.

claims.claim: Secondary copyright infringement – vicarious infringement based on Claude’s use and output of plaintiffs’ song lyrics.
claims.legal_basis: Copyright Act, vicarious infringement doctrine (secondary liability).
claims.outcome: Dismissed on motion to dismiss because plaintiffs did not sufficiently allege direct infringement by third parties, Anthropic’s right and ability to supervise that infringement, or a direct financial benefit from specific infringing acts; dismissal with leave to amend.

claims.claim: Removal or alteration of copyright management information related to plaintiffs’ song lyrics used in training and outputs of Claude.
claims.legal_basis: Digital Millennium Copyright Act (DMCA), provisions on removal of copyright management information (17 U.S.C. § 1202).
claims.outcome: Dismissed on motion to dismiss for insufficiently specific allegations that Anthropic intentionally removed or altered copyright management information knowing it would facilitate infringement; dismissal with leave to amend.

defenses.defense: Failure to state a claim for contributory infringement due to lack of adequately pled direct infringement by any third party and insufficient allegations of Anthropic’s knowledge and material contribution.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6); contributory infringement standards under the Copyright Act.

defenses.defense: Failure to state a claim for vicarious infringement because plaintiffs did not plausibly allege Anthropic’s right and ability to supervise specific infringing conduct or that it received a direct financial benefit from such infringement.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6); vicarious infringement standards under the Copyright Act.

defenses.defense: Failure to state a claim under the DMCA for removal of copyright management information because plaintiffs did not plead specific instances of CMI removal or Anthropic’s knowledge and intent as required by statute.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6); 17 U.S.C. § 1202 (DMCA CMI provisions).

case_id: 2023-08-18_USCOURTS-dcd-1_22-cv-01564_THALER v. PERLMUTTER et al.pdf
case_name: Thaler v. Perlmutter et al.
ai_relevance: Dispute over copyrightability of artwork autonomously generated by an AI system.
ai_presence: The case centers on Stephen Thaler’s attempt to register a copyright in a piece of visual art that he asserted was “autonomously generated by an AI system” he created, called the “Creativity Machine.” The U.S. Copyright Office denied registration because the work lacked human authorship, explaining that current U.S. copyright law protects only works of human authors. Thaler argued that the AI system, operating without human involvement, generated the artwork and that he should be recognized as the copyright owner. The court’s opinion repeatedly discusses artificial intelligence, the “Creativity Machine,” and works “generated entirely by an artificial intelligence system, without any human involvement.” The court ultimately held that copyright protection requires human authorship and that works created autonomously by AI systems, without human creativity or intervention, are not eligible for copyright protection.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual AI developer and copyright applicant
parties.defendant_description: U.S. Copyright Office officials and related government defendants

claims.claim: Challenge to denial of copyright registration for AI-generated artwork.
claims.legal_basis: Administrative Procedure Act and U.S. Copyright Act; alleging the Copyright Office’s refusal to register the work was arbitrary, capricious, contrary to law, and based on an incorrect interpretation that authors must be human.
claims.outcome: Court rejected the challenge and granted judgment for defendants, upholding the Copyright Office’s denial of registration because the work lacked human authorship and is ineligible for copyright protection.

claims.claim: Assertion that a work generated entirely by an AI system is eligible for copyright, with Thaler as the owner.
claims.legal_basis: Interpretation of the Copyright Act’s authorship and originality requirements; argument that the statute does not expressly limit authorship to humans and that AI-generated works should be registrable with Thaler as claimant.
claims.outcome: Court held that U.S. copyright law requires human authorship; works created autonomously by AI systems without human involvement are not copyrightable, so Thaler cannot obtain registration or ownership on that basis.

defenses.defense: Human authorship is a prerequisite for copyright protection.
defenses.legal_basis: Text, structure, and history of the U.S. Copyright Act; longstanding judicial precedent that “author” means a human being and that copyright protects the fruits of human creativity, not autonomous machine output.

defenses.defense: The Copyright Office properly denied registration because the work lacked human authorship.
defenses.legal_basis: Administrative Procedure Act standards for agency action; the Office’s refusal to register a work created solely by an AI system was reasonable, consistent with statute and precedent, and not arbitrary or capricious.

case_id: 2024-08-14_USCOURTS-cand-3_24-cv-06049_Samsara Inc. v. Motive Technologies Inc..pdf
case_name: Samsara Inc. v. Motive Technologies Inc.
ai_relevance: Dispute centers on AI-powered dashboard camera and driver safety technology allegedly copied and infringed by defendant.
ai_presence: The summary describes Samsara Inc. as "a company providing AI-powered dashboard cameras" and states that the case involves "stealing proprietary technology and infringing patents related to driver safety technology." These references indicate that the products at issue use artificial intelligence in their dashboard camera systems for driver safety.

parties.plaintiff_description: Technology corporation providing AI-powered dashboard cameras
parties.defendant_description: Technology corporation offering driver safety telematics products

claims.claim: Misappropriation or theft of proprietary driver safety and dashboard camera technology.
claims.legal_basis: Trade secret and proprietary technology misappropriation under applicable state and/or federal law (exact statutes not specified in summary).
claims.outcome: Substantive claim not decided; case transferred to the Northern District of California under 28 U.S.C. § 1404(a) for further proceedings.

claims.claim: Patent infringement relating to driver safety and AI-powered dashboard camera technology.
claims.legal_basis: Patent infringement under federal patent law (35 U.S.C. §§ 271 et seq., implied from context).
claims.outcome: Substantive patent issues not decided; case transferred to the Northern District of California under 28 U.S.C. § 1404(a) for further proceedings.

claims.claim: Opposition to transfer of venue from Delaware to the Northern District of California (plaintiff’s position to keep case in Delaware).
claims.legal_basis: Argument under 28 U.S.C. § 1404(a) that Delaware is a proper and more convenient forum or that transfer is not in the interest of justice.
claims.outcome: Rejected; the court granted the motion to transfer the case to the Northern District of California.

defenses.defense: Request to transfer venue from the District of Delaware to the Northern District of California for convenience and justice.
defenses.legal_basis: 28 U.S.C. § 1404(a) (transfer of venue for convenience of parties and witnesses and in the interest of justice).

case_id: 2024-07-19_USCOURTS-mad-1_24-cv-10446_Overjet_ Inc. v. VideaHealth_ Inc..pdf
case_name: Overjet, Inc. v. Videa Health, Inc.
ai_relevance: Dispute between dental AI companies over AI-based X‑ray annotation displays and marketing of AI capabilities.
ai_presence: Overjet, a dental AI company, utilizes AI to detect dental diseases by analyzing dental X-rays. Videa allegedly falsely promoted its own AI capabilities and copied Overjet’s AI-generated X-ray annotation color schemes and shapes.

parties.plaintiff_description: Dental artificial intelligence software company
parties.defendant_description: Competing dental AI software company

claims.claim: Copyright infringement based on Videa’s alleged copying of Overjet’s colors, shapes, and shades used to annotate dental X-rays in its AI software interface.
claims.legal_basis: Federal copyright law (alleged protectable audiovisual/graphic elements).
claims.outcome: Preliminary injunction denied; court found Overjet had not shown a likelihood of success on the merits of its copyright claim at this stage.

claims.claim: False advertising based on Videa’s alleged misrepresentations about the nature and capabilities of its dental AI technology.
claims.legal_basis: Lanham Act false advertising provisions, 15 U.S.C. § 1125(a).
claims.outcome: Preliminary injunction denied; court held Overjet had not shown a likelihood of success on the merits of its false advertising claim at this stage.

claims.claim: Request for preliminary injunction to stop Videa from using the challenged X-ray annotation designs and from engaging in alleged false advertising during the litigation.
claims.legal_basis: Equitable relief standard for preliminary injunction (likelihood of success, irreparable harm, balance of hardships, public interest).
claims.outcome: Denied; court concluded Overjet failed to show likelihood of success on its claims or irreparable harm absent an injunction.

defenses.defense: The color schemes, shapes, and shades used to annotate dental X-rays are not protectable by copyright (functional, common, or insufficiently original).
defenses.legal_basis: Copyright law limits on protectability of functional or non-original design elements.

defenses.defense: Videa’s advertising about its AI capabilities is not false or misleading, or is non-actionable marketing puffery, and does not violate the Lanham Act.
defenses.legal_basis: Lanham Act false advertising standards requiring falsity or misleadingness and materiality.

defenses.defense: Overjet cannot show irreparable harm or meet the equitable factors required for a preliminary injunction.
defenses.legal_basis: Preliminary injunction standard under federal law (e.g., Winter factors).

case_id: 2016-02-24_USCOURTS-cand-4_15-cv-00798_Loop AI Labs_ Inc. v. Gatti et al.pdf
case_name: Loop AI Labs, Inc. v. Gatti et al.
ai_relevance: Dispute arises from alleged misappropriation of Loop AI’s artificial intelligence technology and related trade secrets by former CEO and others.
ai_presence: "Loop AI Labs, Inc., a startup developing artificial intelligence technology, filed a lawsuit against several defendants, including its former CEO Anna Gatti, accusing her of misappropriating trade secrets and engaging in unfair competition."

parties.plaintiff_description: Startup technology corporation developing artificial intelligence systems
parties.defendant_description: Former CEO and associated individual and business defendants

claims.claim: Misappropriation of trade secrets related to Loop AI’s technology and confidential business information
claims.legal_basis: Trade secret misappropriation under applicable state and/or federal trade secret law
claims.outcome: Not resolved in this order; the order only addresses a discovery dispute over a subpoena to Orrick and partially grants Orrick’s motion to quash.

claims.claim: Unfair competition arising from alleged misuse of Loop AI’s proprietary AI technology and business information
claims.legal_basis: Unfair competition under applicable state unfair competition statutes and common law
claims.outcome: Not resolved in this order; underlying claim remains pending while the subpoena to Orrick is largely quashed.

claims.claim: Enforcement of subpoena to Orrick for production of internal communications and related documents
claims.legal_basis: Federal Rules of Civil Procedure governing discovery and subpoenas; challenge based on attorney-client privilege and work-product doctrine
claims.outcome: Court grants Orrick’s motion to quash in substantial part, holding most requested documents are privileged; only two emails involving an attorney no longer with Orrick, and not covered by privilege, must be produced.

defenses.defense: Orrick’s internal communications about its representation and ethical obligations are protected by attorney-client privilege and work-product doctrine
defenses.legal_basis: Attorney-client privilege and work-product protections under federal common law and professional responsibility rules

defenses.defense: Concurrent or past simultaneous representation of Loop and other defendants does not waive Orrick’s internal privilege as to its own in-firm legal consultations
defenses.legal_basis: Law-firm internal privilege doctrine and conflict-of-interest rules under professional conduct standards

defenses.defense: Communications not involving legal advice or including third parties (e.g., former attorney no longer at firm) fall outside privilege, but the remainder should be shielded
defenses.legal_basis: Limits of attorney-client privilege where no legal advice is sought or where third parties defeat confidentiality

case_id: 2017-05-01_USCOURTS-ca13-16-01999_EMC Corporation v. Clouding Corp..pdf
case_name: EMC Corporation v. Clouding Corp.
ai_relevance: Patent concerns an AI-based system for diagnosing and solving computer system issues, and obviousness is evaluated in light of prior-art references.
ai_presence: "The technology in question involves an AI-based system for diagnosing and solving computer system issues."

parties.plaintiff_description: Technology corporation challenging patent validity
parties.defendant_description: Corporation owning the challenged patent

claims.claim: Petition for inter partes review challenging Clouding Corp.’s patent claims as obvious over prior art, including the step of saving the state of the computer system when a solution cannot be determined.
claims.legal_basis: 35 U.S.C. § 103 (obviousness) based on combination of Barnett and Allen prior-art references.
claims.outcome: PTAB initially held the challenged claims not unpatentable for obviousness; Federal Circuit vacated and remanded for the PTAB to reconsider obviousness in light of the combined teachings of Barnett and Allen, particularly regarding saving the system state when no solution can be determined.

defenses.defense: The challenged patent claims, including the step of saving the state of the computer system when a solution cannot be determined, are not obvious over the cited prior art.
defenses.legal_basis: 35 U.S.C. § 103; arguments before PTAB that Barnett and Allen, alone or in combination, do not teach or suggest the contested claim limitations.

case_id: 2025-01-08_USCOURTS-cand-4_24-cv-02655_Dubus et al v. NVIDIA Corporation.pdf
case_name: Dubus et al v. NVIDIA Corporation (consolidated with Nazemian v. NVIDIA Inc.)
ai_relevance: Case concerns protection of NVIDIA’s proprietary AI and machine-learning technology, including source code, non-public ML models, and algorithm specifications, during discovery via a protective order.
