defenses.defense: The patent claims lack an inventive concept beyond generic computer implementation of longstanding human practices for screening operator impairment.
defenses.legal_basis: 35 U.S.C. § 101; requirement of an inventive concept under Alice/Mayo framework.
defenses.outcome: Accepted by the court; claims found to lack an inventive concept and thus invalid.

case_id: 2024-04-18_USCOURTS-ca10-22-01402_Underwood_ et al v. Bank of America Corporation.pdf
case_name: Underwood et al. v. Bank of America Corporation
ai_relevance: Dispute over trademarks for virtual assistant services, including BofA’s AI-powered “ERICA” financial assistant and plaintiffs’ claimed “E.R.I.C.A.” virtual assistant mark.
ai_presence: The case involves Bank of America’s “ERICA,” described as a virtual financial assistant, and plaintiffs’ claimed service mark “E.R.I.C.A.” for a virtual assistant. The lawsuit centers on whether BofA’s use of the ERICA virtual assistant mark infringed plaintiffs’ alleged prior rights in their own virtual assistant mark, making the AI-based assistant technology central to the trademark dispute.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual entrepreneur and associated news/media corporation
parties.defendant_description: Large national banking and financial services corporation

claims.claim: Trademark infringement of unregistered service mark “E.R.I.C.A.” by BofA’s use of “ERICA” for its virtual financial assistant.
claims.legal_basis: Lanham Act § 43(a) (15 U.S.C. § 1125(a)) – infringement of unregistered mark based on prior use in commerce.
claims.outcome: Summary judgment for Bank of America; court held plaintiffs lacked a protectable interest because they failed to show actual use in commerce that clearly distinguished and identified their services.

claims.claim: Unfair competition and false designation of origin based on BofA’s use of “ERICA” allegedly causing confusion with plaintiffs’ “E.R.I.C.A.” services.
claims.legal_basis: Lanham Act § 43(a) (15 U.S.C. § 1125(a)) – unfair competition/false designation of origin.
claims.outcome: Summary judgment for Bank of America; without a protectable interest in the “E.R.I.C.A.” mark, plaintiffs’ unfair competition and false designation claims failed.

claims.claim: Related state-law trademark and unfair competition claims premised on alleged prior rights in the “E.R.I.C.A.” mark.
claims.legal_basis: State common-law trademark infringement and unfair competition (jurisdiction-specific doctrines paralleling Lanham Act).
claims.outcome: Summary judgment for Bank of America; state-law claims failed because plaintiffs did not establish protectable trademark rights through actual use in commerce.

defenses.defense: Plaintiffs never established a protectable interest in the unregistered “E.R.I.C.A.” mark because they did not show actual use in commerce that clearly distinguished their services.
defenses.legal_basis: Lanham Act requirement of prior actual use in commerce to create rights in an unregistered mark; burden on plaintiff to prove protectable interest.

defenses.defense: Without a valid, protectable mark, there can be no likelihood of confusion or infringement by BofA’s use of “ERICA.”
defenses.legal_basis: Elements of trademark infringement and unfair competition under the Lanham Act and parallel state law require a valid mark as a threshold.

defenses.defense: Summary judgment appropriate because plaintiffs’ evidence of use of “E.R.I.C.A.” was insufficient as a matter of law to show distinct source-identifying use.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 56; case law on summary judgment in trademark disputes where plaintiff cannot show sufficient use in commerce.

case_id: 2025-09-16_USCOURTS-cand-5_24-cv-03811_Concord Music Group_ Inc. et al v. Anthropic PBC.pdf
case_name: Concord Music Group, Inc. et al v. Anthropic PBC
ai_relevance: Defendant allegedly used plaintiffs’ copyrighted songs to train an AI tool, raising novel copyright and damages issues related to AI training on protected works.
ai_presence: The summary states that plaintiffs allege Anthropic "used copyright-protected songs to train its AI tool." The court notes this is a "novel intersection of copyright law and AI technology" and adopts a pragmatic approach to Rule 26 damages disclosure requirements in light of the AI training context.

parties.plaintiff_name: Concord Music Group, Inc. et al
parties.plaintiff_description: Music publishers and related rights holders
parties.defendant_description: Artificial intelligence technology company

claims.claim: Copyright infringement based on alleged unauthorized use of plaintiffs’ songs to train Anthropic’s AI tool.
claims.legal_basis: Copyright Act – infringement of exclusive rights in musical works and related copyrights.
claims.outcome: Not resolved in this order; litigation continues. The court only addressed the adequacy and timing of plaintiffs’ Rule 26 damages disclosures.

claims.claim: Claim for monetary damages for alleged copyright infringement, including computation of damages related to AI training use.
claims.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 26(a)(1)(A)(iii) governing initial disclosure of a computation of each category of damages claimed.
claims.outcome: Court held current disclosures were insufficiently detailed but denied Anthropic’s request to immediately supplement or to exclude damages evidence. Ordered plaintiffs to provide more detailed damages computations by the close of fact discovery.

defenses.defense: Challenge to sufficiency of plaintiffs’ damages computation disclosures and request to bar or limit damages evidence.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 26(a)(1)(A)(iii) and Rule 37(c)(1) (seeking supplementation or exclusion as a sanction for inadequate disclosures).

defenses.defense: Practical objection that plaintiffs’ current damages disclosures do not provide enough detail for Anthropic to understand or test the claimed damages related to AI training.
defenses.legal_basis: Discovery obligations and proportionality principles under the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure, including Rule 26(b) and (g).

case_id: 2025-11-04_USCOURTS-cand-3_24-cv-01451_In Re Mosaic LLM Litigation.pdf
case_name: In Re Mosaic LLM Litigation
ai_relevance: Central discovery dispute over generative AI models, AI tools, and licensing of training data for AI systems, including relevance to fair use and market impact analyses.
ai_presence: The case summary states this is “a lawsuit related to AI technology” and that “the involvement of AI is central to the disputes over what data and documents are relevant to determining issues of fair use and licensing in relation to generative AI models.” Defendants sought discovery about “the plaintiffs' use and knowledge of AI tools, and documents related to licensing agreements for AI training data.” They requested broad electronic search terms “linked to third-party AI tools and licensing agreements for AI training data,” including mentions of “AI tools like ChatGPT and agreements about using their data for AI training.” The court found these AI-related search terms overly broad and not sufficiently relevant to the asserted fair use defense and market impact issues, but allowed defendants to propose a limited number of more focused AI-related search terms instead.

parties.plaintiff_description: Putative class of copyright holders challenging AI training
parties.defendant_description: Companies behind Mosaic-related generative AI models

claims.claim: Copyright infringement and related claims arising from use of plaintiffs’ works to train generative AI models.
claims.legal_basis: U.S. copyright law, including exclusive rights and alleged unauthorized reproduction for AI training; fair use and market harm at issue in discovery.
claims.outcome: Not resolved in this discovery order; litigation continues. Order only addresses scope of electronic discovery.

claims.claim: Plaintiffs’ discovery position that they need not run defendants’ broad AI-related search terms across their ESI because those terms are irrelevant, disproportionate, and unduly burdensome.
claims.legal_basis: Federal Rules of Civil Procedure 26(b)(1) and 34, proportionality and relevance limits on discovery.
claims.outcome: Court agreed in substantial part with plaintiffs and denied defendants’ request to compel use of the broad AI-related search terms.

claims.claim: Defendants’ request that plaintiffs be compelled to identify and disclose locations where plaintiffs’ works are available online, to assess availability and potential market impact relevant to fair use.
claims.legal_basis: Federal Rules of Civil Procedure 26(b)(1) and 34; relevance to fair use factors, including market effect and availability of works.
claims.outcome: Court granted in part: required plaintiffs to supplement discovery responses with a reasonable effort to identify locations where their works are available online.

defenses.defense: Defendants’ fair use defense to alleged copyright infringement by training and operating generative AI models on plaintiffs’ works.
defenses.legal_basis: U.S. copyright law fair use doctrine, 17 U.S.C. § 107, including factors such as purpose and character of use and market effect.

defenses.defense: Defendants’ argument that broad discovery into plaintiffs’ use and knowledge of AI tools and AI training-data licenses is relevant to assessing fair use and market impact.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 26(b)(1) on scope of discovery tied to claims and defenses; relevance to fair use analysis.

case_id: 2006-02-14_USCOURTS-waed-2_05-cv-00380_Next It Corporation v. Roy et al.pdf
case_name: Next IT Corporation v. Joshua Knowles (and others)
ai_relevance: Dispute over proprietary artificial intelligence application technology and related trade secrets.
ai_presence: The summary states the dispute concerns "Next IT's proprietary technology related to artificial intelligence applications" and that the case centers on "allegations that Knowles might possess or misuse Next IT's proprietary technology related to artificial intelligence applications."

parties.plaintiff_description: Technology corporation providing AI software applications
parties.defendant_description: Former employee, individual software technologist

claims.claim: Misappropriation and threatened misappropriation of proprietary and trade secret technology information Knowles accessed during his employment.
claims.legal_basis: Trade secret and proprietary information law; contractual and common-law duties of confidentiality.
claims.outcome: Resolved by stipulated permanent injunction: Knowles is indefinitely enjoined from disclosing any proprietary information of Next IT.

claims.claim: Unfair competition and competitive use of Next IT’s confidential technology in software applications that compete with Next IT.
claims.legal_basis: Unfair competition and trade secret law; post-employment restrictive covenants.
claims.outcome: Resolved by stipulated injunction: for three years Knowles is prohibited from engaging in activities that compete with Next IT software applications or involve similar technology.

claims.claim: Interference with Next IT’s employment relationships by recruiting or attempting to recruit its current employees.
claims.legal_basis: Common-law interference with contractual or business relationships; non-solicitation obligations.
claims.outcome: Resolved by stipulated injunction: for one year Knowles is prohibited from recruiting current employees of Next IT.

claims.claim: Potential reputational harm through disparaging or defamatory statements between the parties.
claims.legal_basis: Defamation and related reputational tort principles, addressed by agreement.
claims.outcome: Resolved by mutual non-defamation agreement incorporated into the stipulated order.

defenses.defense: Resolution by stipulation without admission of liability, agreeing to injunctive terms instead of litigating merits.
defenses.legal_basis: Contractual settlement and stipulated injunction approved by the court.

case_id: 2024-09-25_USCOURTS-ksd-5_15-cv-03098_Jones _ID 59073_ v. United States Copyright Office and Patents.pdf
case_name: Jones v. United States Copyright Office and Patents
ai_relevance: Plaintiff sought copyright and patent protections for his artificial intelligence research and related submissions.
ai_presence: The summary states: "the plaintiff sought mandamus relief to obtain forms for copyright and patent submissions related to his research on artificial intelligence" and "The case involves AI as the plaintiff's submissions were focused on obtaining intellectual property rights for his AI research."

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual prisoner litigant seeking IP forms
parties.defendant_name: United States Copyright Office and Patents
parties.defendant_description: Federal intellectual property offices and related agencies

claims.claim: Request for writ of mandamus compelling provision of copyright and patent submission forms for his artificial intelligence research and related works.
claims.legal_basis: Mandamus relief under federal law to compel government officials/agencies to perform a nondiscretionary duty.
claims.outcome: Dismissed because plaintiff failed to pay the required district court filing fee as a prisoner subject to the three-strikes rule; case closed.

claims.claim: Post-judgment motions seeking relief from the prior dismissal and reopening of the case so he could pursue mandamus and obtain copyright and patent forms for his AI research.
claims.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 60(b) (relief from a final judgment, order, or proceeding).
claims.outcome: Denied; the court held plaintiff failed to show exceptional circumstances or any valid Rule 60(b) ground, so judgment stood and the case remained closed.

defenses.defense: Plaintiff, as a prisoner with three prior strikes, was required to pay the full filing fee and failed to do so, justifying dismissal of the action.
defenses.legal_basis: 28 U.S.C. § 1915(g) (Prison Litigation Reform Act three-strikes rule) and district court filing-fee requirements.

defenses.defense: No exceptional circumstances or qualifying grounds under Rule 60(b) to disturb the prior judgment dismissing the case.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 60(b) standards for relief from judgment, including requirement of extraordinary or exceptional circumstances.

case_id: 2021-02-23_USCOURTS-ksd-5_15-cv-03098_Jones _ID 59073_ v. United States Copyright Office and Patents.pdf
case_name: Jones v. United States Copyright Office and Patents
ai_relevance: Plaintiff’s underlying research concerns artificial intelligence and related intellectual property protections.
ai_presence: The summary states the plaintiff sought mandamus relief related to “his published research on artificial intelligence (AI)” and his ability to obtain and file copyright, patent, or trademark forms for that AI-related work and for a “Fractal.”

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual prisoner and pro se litigant
parties.defendant_description: Federal government intellectual property agencies and offices

claims.claim: Request for mandamus relief compelling access to copyright and patent forms for his published AI research and for filing to patent or trademark a “Fractal.”
claims.legal_basis: Petition for writ of mandamus; access to federal copyright and patent application processes.
claims.outcome: Dismissed at screening under the Prison Litigation Reform Act “3-strike” rule; case not allowed to proceed without full filing fee.

claims.claim: Request to be relieved from paying the full district court filing fee despite being subject to the “3-strike” rule, based on his copyright and patent form-access claims.
claims.legal_basis: Challenge to application of 28 U.S.C. § 1915(g) (three-strikes provision) and request to proceed without prepayment of fees.
claims.outcome: Denied; court enforced the three-strikes rule and required full filing fee.

claims.claim: Motion for relief from judgment arguing the prior dismissal and fee requirement were erroneous and should be set aside.
claims.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 60(b) (relief from judgment).
claims.outcome: Denied; court found no grounds under Rule 60(b), no exceptional circumstances, and held the motion was untimely.

defenses.defense: Plaintiff is barred from proceeding in forma pauperis due to prior dismissals and must pay the full filing fee unless under imminent danger of serious physical injury.
defenses.legal_basis: 28 U.S.C. § 1915(g) Prison Litigation Reform Act “3-strike” rule.

defenses.defense: No basis for relief from judgment because plaintiff showed no mistake, new evidence, fraud, or other exceptional circumstances, and his Rule 60(b) motion was untimely.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 60(b) standards for relief from final judgment and timeliness requirements.

case_id: 2024-09-12_USCOURTS-mied-2_24-cv-11786_Robinson v. Global Semiconductor Alliance.pdf
case_name: Robinson v. Global Semiconductor Alliance
ai_relevance: Plaintiff alleges his patented Fiber-Optic Connected Logic (FOCL) is being used without authorization to run various AI programs, forming the core of the alleged infringement dispute.
ai_presence: The plaintiff alleges that unnamed entities are utilizing his patented Fiber-Optic Connected Logic (FOCL) to run various AI programs without authorization. The case summary notes that Robinson believes his patent is being used to support AI programs without proper authorization.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual patent holder and inventor
parties.defendant_description: Industry organization in semiconductor sector

claims.claim: Patent infringement based on alleged unauthorized use of Fiber-Optic Connected Logic (FOCL) to run AI programs.
claims.legal_basis: Federal patent law (infringement of patented technology).
claims.outcome: Dismissed without prejudice for failure to state a claim; court found the complaint lacked sufficient factual detail tying any infringing conduct to the named defendant, GSA.

defenses.defense: Complaint fails to state a claim because it does not plausibly allege that GSA engaged in any specific infringing conduct.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal pleading standards under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 8 and 12(b)(6) (plausibility requirement).

case_id: 2016-03-30_USCOURTS-paed-2_15-cv-05387_DUCKWEED_ USA_ INC. et al v. BEHRENS et al.pdf
case_name: Duckweed, USA, Inc. et al. v. Behrens et al.
ai_relevance: Licensed clean‑energy technology allegedly required an essential “artificial intelligence” component to operate the systems at issue, and this AI-based functionality formed part of the patented technology Duckweed claimed was infringed.
ai_presence: Duckweed claimed its licensed technology involved an essential "artificial intelligence" component necessary for operating certain clean-energy systems.

parties.plaintiff_description: Corporation licensing clean-energy patent technology
parties.defendant_description: Individual patent owner and additional defendants

claims.claim: Patent infringement
claims.legal_basis: Federal patent law; infringement of an exclusively licensed patent by unauthorized use, including by the original patent owner and others
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied as to standing; court held Duckweed had standing to sue for patent infringement based on its exclusive license, even though the alleged infringer was the original patent owner.

claims.claim: Civil conspiracy to breach the license agreement
claims.legal_basis: State civil conspiracy law requiring an underlying tort in addition to breach of contract
claims.outcome: Dismissed; court held civil conspiracy cannot be based solely on a breach of contract without an independent underlying tort.

defenses.defense: Duckweed lacks standing to sue for patent infringement because it is only a licensee and the patent owner is a necessary party
defenses.legal_basis: Patent standing doctrine requiring suits to be brought by the patentee or an exclusive licensee with all substantial rights, and joinder rules for patent owners
defenses.defense_outcome: Rejected; court found Duckweed held an exclusive license and fell within an exception because the patentee was the alleged infringer and could not sue himself, so Duckweed had standing.

defenses.defense: Civil conspiracy claim fails because it is based solely on breach of contract without an underlying tort
defenses.legal_basis: State law principle that civil conspiracy requires an underlying actionable tort, not merely a contract breach
defenses.defense_outcome: Accepted; court dismissed Duckweed’s civil conspiracy to breach the license agreement claim.

case_id: 2025-04-03_USCOURTS-jpml-1_24-F-03143_IN RE_ OpenAI_ Inc._ Copyright Infringement Litigation.pdf
case_name: In re OpenAI Inc. Copyright Infringement Litigation
ai_relevance: Dispute over training large language models like GPT-4 on copyrighted works without consent.
ai_presence: The case concerns “copyright infringement related to their use of copyrighted works without consent for training large language models (LLMs) like GPT-4.” It also refers to “how this robot was taught,” describing AI models trained on books and articles to “teach its robot how to talk and answer questions.”

parties.plaintiff_description: Authors and rightsholders alleging copyright infringement.
parties.defendant_description: AI developer and technology corporation defendants.

claims.claim: Copyright infringement based on use of copyrighted works to train LLMs without consent.
claims.legal_basis: Federal copyright law prohibiting unauthorized reproduction and use of protected works.
claims.outcome: No merits ruling; actions centralized in the Southern District of New York for coordinated pretrial proceedings.

claims.claim: Related claims arising from alleged misuse of copyrighted materials in AI training (e.g., derivative works, unfair competition, or similar).
claims.legal_basis: Associated federal and possibly state intellectual property and related laws.
claims.outcome: No merits ruling; included within the centralized multidistrict litigation in the Southern District of New York.

defenses.defense: Opposition to centralization based on differences in claims among actions.
defenses.legal_basis: Arguments under multidistrict litigation standards that cases are too dissimilar for consolidation.

case_id: 2022-11-28_USCOURTS-cofc-1_21-cv-01295_ALJINDI v. USA.pdf
case_name: Aljindi v. United States
ai_relevance: Plaintiff alleged infringement of scientific work involving Information Security, Artificial Intelligence, and Legacy Information Systems.
ai_presence: The summary states that the plaintiff claimed the federal government infringed on his intellectual property "specifically related to scientific work on Information Security, Artificial Intelligence (AI), and Legacy Information Systems (LIS)."

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual alleging IP infringement by federal government
parties.defendant_description: Federal government of the United States

claims.claim: Copyright infringement of plaintiff’s scientific work on Information Security, Artificial Intelligence, and Legacy Information Systems by the federal government.
claims.legal_basis: Federal copyright law; alleged unauthorized use of plaintiff’s intellectual property by the United States.
claims.outcome: Dismissed for failure to state a plausible claim because the asserted rights concerned uncopyrightable ideas, concepts, principles, and discoveries rather than protectable expression.

claims.claim: Request for summary judgment in plaintiff’s favor on his copyright infringement claims.
claims.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure standards for summary judgment (no genuine dispute of material fact and entitlement to judgment as a matter of law).
claims.outcome: Denied as futile because the underlying complaint failed to state a claim upon which relief could be granted.

defenses.defense: Plaintiff seeks copyright protection over ideas, concepts, principles, and discoveries, which are not copyrightable subject matter.
defenses.legal_basis: Copyright law limitation that ideas, procedures, processes, systems, methods of operation, concepts, principles, or discoveries are not protected (e.g., 17 U.S.C. § 102(b)).

defenses.defense: Complaint fails to state a plausible claim for relief under copyright law.
defenses.legal_basis: Failure to state a claim upon which relief can be granted (Rule 12(b)(6) standard).

case_id: 2019-05-07_USCOURTS-ilnd-1_18-cv-07246_CCC Intelligent Solutions Inc v. Tractable Inc..pdf
case_name: CCC Information Services Inc. v. Tractable Inc.
ai_relevance: Dispute centers on Tractable’s AI system that generates real-time vehicle repair estimates from photos, allegedly built using fraudulently obtained access to CCC’s proprietary CCC ONE estimating software and data.
ai_presence: The case summary explains that Tractable uses artificial intelligence to produce real-time cost estimates from vehicle damage pictures, in contrast to CCC’s CCC ONE product, which requires physical vehicle inspection by appraisers. Tractable allegedly accessed CCC’s proprietary CCC ONE software and data to benefit its AI-driven estimating system. The opinion notes that Tractable’s technology enables automated, AI-based assessment of vehicle damage and repair costs, which is at the heart of the competitive and contractual dispute between the parties.

parties.plaintiff_description: Corporation providing auto claims software solutions
parties.defendant_description: Corporation offering AI vehicle damage assessment

claims.claim: Fraudulent access and use of CCC’s proprietary CCC ONE software and data for Tractable’s benefit.
claims.legal_basis: Common-law fraud and related misrepresentation/unlawful access theories under applicable state law (as pled in the complaint).
claims.outcome: Underlying fraud and related claims were not resolved in this decision; the court only denied Tractable’s motion to compel arbitration, allowing CCC’s claims to proceed in court.

claims.claim: Breach or invalidity of any purported agreement to arbitrate disputes arising from Tractable’s access to CCC ONE.
claims.legal_basis: Contract law principles requiring a valid, mutual agreement to arbitrate; challenge to formation and enforceability of any arbitration agreement.
claims.outcome: Court held there was no valid agreement to arbitrate between CCC and Tractable; Tractable’s motion to compel arbitration was denied.

defenses.defense: CCC’s claims must be resolved in arbitration pursuant to an arbitration clause allegedly applicable to disputes arising from use of CCC ONE.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Arbitration Act and contract law enforcing arbitration agreements when parties have agreed to arbitrate.

defenses.defense: Tractable stood in the shoes of, or was a beneficiary/assignee of, an existing user agreement containing an arbitration provision, thereby binding CCC to arbitrate with Tractable.
defenses.legal_basis: Contract doctrines of third‑party beneficiary, assignment, and equitable enforcement of arbitration clauses.

case_id: 2019-05-07_USCOURTS-cand-5_18-cv-04327_Lamont v. Conner et al.pdf
case_name: Lamont v. Conner et al.
ai_relevance: Plaintiff alleges Google misused his confidential information to enhance its artificial intelligence capabilities after a meeting where he claims to have shared trade secrets without an NDA.
ai_presence: The summary states that Plaintiff alleged Google "misused his trade secrets to boost its AI capabilities after a meeting in which confidential information was allegedly shared without an NDA."

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual alleging trade secret misappropriation
parties.defendant_description: Corporate defendants affiliated with Google Ventures and Alphabet

claims.claim: Misappropriation of trade secrets by Google Ventures and Alphabet Inc. based on alleged misuse of confidential information shared during a meeting to enhance Google’s AI capabilities.
claims.legal_basis: Defend Trade Secrets Act of 2016 and related trade secret principles for preliminary injunction standard.
claims.outcome: Preliminary injunction denied; court found Plaintiff failed to show a likelihood of success on the merits of his trade secret claims and failed to demonstrate irreparable harm.

defenses.defense: Plaintiff failed to demonstrate a likelihood of success on the merits of his trade secret misappropriation claims.
defenses.legal_basis: Preliminary injunction standard under federal law requiring a clear showing of likely success on the merits.

defenses.defense: Plaintiff failed to show irreparable harm absent an injunction.
defenses.legal_basis: Preliminary injunction standard under federal law requiring proof of irreparable harm.

case_id: 2024-03-14_USCOURTS-cand-5_23-cv-05181_Playground AI LLC v. Mighty Computing_ Inc. et al.pdf
case_name: Playground AI LLC v. Mighty Computing, Inc., et al.
ai_relevance: Both parties operate in the artificial intelligence sector and dispute use of the “Playground AI” mark in connection with AI-related products and services.
ai_presence: The summary states: “This case involves a trademark dispute between Playground AI LLC and Mighty Computing, Inc., both operating in the artificial intelligence sector, over the use of the 'Playground AI' mark.” It further notes that the companies are “in the artificial intelligence sector” and that the contested mark is “Playground AI.”

parties.plaintiff_description: Limited liability company in AI sector
parties.defendant_description: AI-sector corporation and its individual founder

claims.claim: Trademark infringement based on defendants’ use of the 'Playground AI' mark in commerce.
claims.legal_basis: Federal trademark law (Lanham Act) and related trademark infringement principles.
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss as to Suhail Doshi denied; court held plaintiff plausibly alleged his personal liability for trademark infringement, so the claim proceeds against him.

claims.claim: Cybersquatting related to defendants’ registration and/or use of domain names incorporating the 'Playground AI' mark.
claims.legal_basis: Anticybersquatting Consumer Protection Act (ACPA) and related cybersquatting doctrines.
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss as to Suhail Doshi denied; court held plaintiff plausibly alleged his personal liability for cybersquatting, so the claim proceeds against him.

defenses.defense: Corporate officer (Suhail Doshi) cannot be held personally liable for the alleged trademark infringement and cybersquatting of Mighty Computing.
defenses.legal_basis: Corporate separateness and limited liability principles shielding officers from personal liability absent direct involvement or specific wrongful acts.

case_id: 2019-05-14_USCOURTS-cand-5_18-cv-04327_Lamont v. Conner et al.pdf
case_name: Lamont v. Krane et al.
ai_relevance: Dispute over alleged misappropriation of artificial intelligence-related trade secrets.
ai_presence: Plaintiff P. Stephen Lamont accused the defendants of misappropriating trade secrets related to artificial intelligence (AI).

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual alleging AI trade secret theft
parties.defendant_description: Corporate venture capital arm of Google/Alphabet

claims.claim: Misappropriation of trade secrets related to artificial intelligence technology
claims.legal_basis: Defend Trade Secrets Act (DTSA), 18 U.S.C. § 1836 et seq.
claims.outcome: Dismissed on motion to dismiss for failure to state a claim; court found insufficient particularity and evidence of trade secret ownership and misappropriation, and dismissal was without leave to amend.

defenses.defense: Complaint fails to state a plausible claim for trade secret misappropriation due to lack of particularity and factual support.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6) and pleading standards under Twombly/Iqbal for DTSA claims.

defenses.defense: Plaintiff did not adequately allege ownership of the purported trade secrets or wrongful acquisition, disclosure, or use by defendants.
defenses.legal_basis: Substantive requirements of the Defend Trade Secrets Act for ownership and misappropriation elements.

defenses.defense: Further amendment would be futile and would unduly prejudice defendants.
defenses.legal_basis: Court’s discretionary authority to deny leave to amend under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 15(a).

case_id: 2024-11-14_USCOURTS-txwd-1_24-cv-00354_Mullen Industries LLC v. Meta Platforms_ Inc..pdf
case_name: Mullen Industries LLC v. Meta Platforms, Inc.
ai_relevance: Dispute involves alleged infringement of patents covering AI-related functionality in Meta’s augmented and virtual reality systems, including use of artificial intelligence to control or manage in-game or virtual characters and behaviors.
ai_presence: The summary indicates that several of Mullen’s asserted patents include claims “related to wireless telephones, artificial intelligence (AI), and landscape characteristics.” Meta moved to dismiss, in part, on the ground that Mullen’s allegations about “AI usage” were implausible and insufficiently specific. The court “recommended dismissing Counts II and VII, related to AI usage and wireless telephone functionality, with prejudice,” finding that Mullen had not plausibly or specifically alleged how Meta’s products used AI in a way that infringed the asserted patents. Thus, AI is mentioned as a claimed feature of the patented technology (smart, computer-controlled or AI-driven behavior in Meta’s AR/VR systems) and as a focus of Meta’s motion to dismiss for failure to state a sufficiently detailed and plausible infringement theory.

parties.plaintiff_description: Limited liability company patent holder
parties.defendant_description: Technology corporation operating AR/VR platforms

claims.claim: Patent infringement based on Meta’s augmented and virtual reality systems allegedly practicing Mullen’s patented wireless telephone functionality.
claims.legal_basis: Federal patent infringement under 35 U.S.C. § 271 relating to patents covering wireless telephone features integrated into AR/VR devices or systems.
claims.outcome: Dismissed with prejudice (Count II and/or VII) for lack of plausibility and specificity; court denied further leave to amend as futile.

claims.claim: Patent infringement based on Meta’s alleged use of artificial intelligence within its AR/VR products in a manner covered by Mullen’s AI-related patent claims.
claims.legal_basis: Federal patent infringement under 35 U.S.C. § 271 relating to patents claiming AI-based control or behavior in virtual or augmented environments.
claims.outcome: Dismissed with prejudice (Count II and/or VII) due to insufficiently specific and implausible allegations; court refused additional amendment as futile.

claims.claim: Patent infringement based on Meta’s AR/VR systems allegedly using “landscape characteristics” in virtual playfields as claimed in Mullen’s patents.
claims.legal_basis: Federal patent infringement under 35 U.S.C. § 271 relating to patents claiming use or classification of landscape characteristics in virtual or game playfields.
claims.outcome: Allowed to proceed; court declined to dismiss these counts and indicated that further claim construction is required to resolve disputes over “landscape characteristics.”

claims.claim: Patent infringement of additional asserted patents (total of twelve) by Meta’s AR/VR systems beyond the specific wireless telephone and AI-related patents challenged in the motion to dismiss.
claims.legal_basis: Federal patent infringement under 35 U.S.C. § 271 for the remaining asserted patents not dismissed, including those tied to AR/VR functionality and location-based game features.
claims.outcome: Claims corresponding to patents not tied to the dismissed wireless telephone and AI counts were allowed to proceed; Meta’s motion to dismiss was denied as to these counts.

defenses.defense: Mullen’s complaint fails to plausibly allege that Meta’s products practice the claimed wireless telephone functionality.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal pleading standards under Fed. R. Civ. P. 8(a) and 12(b)(6) requiring a plausible claim for relief; argument that allegations are conclusory and implausible.

defenses.defense: Mullen’s allegations of AI usage in Meta’s AR/VR systems are too vague and nonspecific to state a claim for patent infringement.
defenses.legal_basis: Fed. R. Civ. P. 8(a) and 12(b)(6) (failure to state a claim) and case law requiring specific factual allegations tying accused products to asserted patent claims.

defenses.defense: Mullen has already amended its complaint and further amendment would be futile because it has repeatedly failed to cure pleading deficiencies regarding AI and wireless telephone claims.
defenses.legal_basis: Discretion to deny leave to amend under Fed. R. Civ. P. 15(a)(2) when amendment would be futile, based on prior unsuccessful amendments.

defenses.defense: To the extent Mullen’s theories treat AR/VR headsets as “wireless telephones,” such characterization is implausible under the asserted patent claims and cannot support infringement.
defenses.legal_basis: Substantive patent law and claim interpretation principles, invoked at the pleading stage to argue that the asserted reading of “wireless telephone” is legally untenable and thus implausible.

case_id: 2025-03-18_USCOURTS-caDC-23-05233_Stephen Thaler v. Shira Perlmutter_ et al.pdf
case_name: Thaler v. Perlmutter
ai_relevance: Dispute over whether an AI system (“Creativity Machine”) can be an author under the Copyright Act and obtain copyright registration for its output.
ai_presence: The case centers on an artwork created by Dr. Stephen Thaler’s AI system, referred to as the “Creativity Machine.” Thaler attempted to register a copyright for this AI-generated artwork, listing the machine as the sole author. The U.S. Copyright Office denied the application based on its longstanding human-authorship requirement, concluding that a non-human machine cannot be an author. Both the district court and the appellate court upheld this decision, holding that under the Copyright Act of 1976, a work must be authored by a human being to qualify for copyright protection, and that the “Creativity Machine,” as an artificial intelligence, cannot be recognized as an author under the Act.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual AI developer and copyright applicant
parties.defendant_description: U.S. Copyright Office officials, government defendants

claims.claim: Challenge to denial of copyright registration for AI-generated artwork listing the AI “Creativity Machine” as the sole author.
claims.legal_basis: Copyright Act of 1976; administrative review of U.S. Copyright Office refusal to register; argument that the Act permits non-human authorship or that the Office’s human-authorship requirement is unlawful.
claims.outcome: Denied. District court and appellate court upheld the Copyright Office’s refusal, holding that the Copyright Act requires human authorship and that a non-human AI cannot be an author.

defenses.defense: Copyright protection under the Copyright Act is limited to works of human authorship; non-human entities, including AI systems, cannot be authors.
defenses.legal_basis: Statutory interpretation of the Copyright Act of 1976 and longstanding Copyright Office practice requiring human authorship, as recognized and affirmed by the courts.

case_id: 2025-01-29_USCOURTS-txwd-1_24-cv-00354_Mullen Industries LLC v. Meta Platforms_ Inc..pdf
case_name: Mullen Industries LLC v. Meta Platforms, Inc.
ai_relevance: Dispute involves alleged patent infringement by Meta’s AR/VR products, including claims that they use artificial intelligence in ways covered by Mullen’s patents; court found AI-related infringement allegations insufficiently pled and dismissed those counts.
ai_presence: The summary states that Mullen alleged infringement of patents related to augmented and virtual reality technologies, including claims about artificial intelligence. Count VII involved AI claims and was dismissed with prejudice because of a lack of plausible allegations that Meta’s products met essential AI-related claim elements. The court noted that the AI aspects of the asserted patents were insufficiently detailed in the complaint to plausibly show that Meta’s AR/VR technologies satisfied those specific AI claim limitations.

parties.plaintiff_description: Limited liability company patent holder
parties.defendant_description: Large technology corporation, AR/VR products

claims.claim: Patent infringement based on Meta’s AR/VR products allegedly practicing Mullen’s patented technologies (general infringement claim).
claims.legal_basis: Federal patent law, 35 U.S.C. § 271 (Count I).
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied; Count I survives and proceeds to further litigation.

claims.claim: Patent infringement alleging Meta’s AR/VR products qualify as and infringe patents directed to “wireless telephones.”
claims.legal_basis: Federal patent law, 35 U.S.C. § 271 (Count II).
claims.outcome: Dismissed with prejudice on Meta’s motion to dismiss; court held Mullen failed to plausibly allege that Meta’s AR/VR products meet the “wireless telephone” claim elements.

claims.claim: Additional patent infringement claims against Meta’s AR/VR technologies under other asserted Mullen patents (non‑wireless‑telephone, non‑AI counts).
claims.legal_basis: Federal patent law, 35 U.S.C. § 271 (Counts III, IV, V, and IX).
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied; Counts III, IV, V, and IX remain pending and may proceed to discovery and further proceedings.

claims.claim: Patent infringement based on alleged use of artificial intelligence in Meta’s AR/VR products in a manner covered by Mullen’s patents.
claims.legal_basis: Federal patent law, 35 U.S.C. § 271 (Count VII).
claims.outcome: Dismissed with prejudice on Meta’s motion to dismiss; court found Mullen did not plead sufficient factual allegations that Meta’s products satisfied essential AI-related claim elements.

defenses.defense: Failure to state a claim because Meta’s AR/VR products are not plausibly alleged to be “wireless telephones” under the asserted patent claims.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6); patent infringement pleading standards requiring plausible factual allegations that accused products meet each claim limitation.

defenses.defense: Failure to state a claim because the complaint lacks sufficient factual allegations that Meta’s AR/VR products practice the AI-related limitations of the asserted patents.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6); Twombly/Iqbal plausibility standard for patent infringement pleadings, requiring non-conclusory facts showing accused products meet AI claim elements.

case_id: 2014-09-18_USCOURTS-ilnd-1_13-cv-04417_Vehicle Intelligence and Safety LLC v. Mercedes-Benz USA_ LLC et al.pdf
case_name: Vehicle Intelligence and Safety LLC v. Mercedes-Benz USA, LLC et al.
ai_relevance: The patent covers an expert system, a type of artificial intelligence, used to assess operator impairment and control vehicle equipment based on that assessment. The dispute centers on how the AI-based “expert system(s)” is defined for infringement analysis.
ai_presence: The case concerns U.S. Patent No. 7,394,392, titled “Expert System Safety Screening of Equipment Operators.” The court explains that an “expert system” is a type of artificial intelligence used to evaluate the impairment of equipment operators and control equipment based on that assessment. The court holds that the term “expert system(s)” in the ’392 patent refers to a computer program that includes: (1) a database module with information pertinent to assessing operator impairment; (2) a decision module for applying logic to screen and control the equipment; and (3) an interface module connecting with equipment and operators.

parties.plaintiff_description: Patent-holding business entity asserting technology rights
parties.defendant_name: Mercedes-Benz USA, LLC and Daimler AG
parties.defendant_description: Automobile manufacturers accused of patent infringement

claims.claim: Infringement of U.S. Patent No. 7,394,392 relating to an expert system for safety screening of equipment operators by defendants’ vehicle systems.
claims.legal_basis: Federal patent infringement under 35 U.S.C. § 271 based on alleged use of an “expert system” that falls within the scope of the ’392 patent claims.
claims.outcome: In this claim construction order, the court construed “expert system(s)” as a computer program including a database module, decision module, and interface module; ultimate infringement determination is not resolved in this opinion.

defenses.defense: The term “expert system(s)” should be narrowly construed so that defendants’ accused vehicle systems do not fall within the scope of the asserted patent claims.
defenses.legal_basis: Patent claim construction principles under Markman; arguments based on intrinsic evidence (claim language, specification, prosecution history) to limit the meaning of “expert system(s).”
